cons: Nokia has been in a downward spiral for over a decade. During my time there I saw many layoffs and huge increases in the demands on remaining employees.  With the acquisition by Microsoft hopefully things will stabilize.

review_title: Great company that values employees personal issues.
job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Burlington, MA
pros:
Nokia tries to stay very current. They are also a very global company. You will learn things about markets in other parts of the world that you did not think about before.

They respect their employees, and provide nice features in the buildings and benefits that they offer. Very considerate of employees.

Finland is great; if you get a chance to go there on a business trip - TAKE IT!
cons: The effect of aligning too closely with Microsoft meant the end of many promising products that went in other directions. Too bad, since in high tech you really need to keep many future options available.

pros:
I like to work. I always finish what I start. I have a long experience from the telecommunications business from the several jobs. I can do microsaoft and linux/unix based work and small scripts are ok too.
I always try to challenge myself and learn more. Challenges keeps me motivated and it's best thing in work, so I can learn more. Also I have taken a lot of manager courses and learned project manager role. I have not worked like project manager, but took courses and belong to mentoring program where future manager are trained.
cons: I don't know so much downsides. I like to work, maybe if work is night time.

job_title: Embedded Software Developer in Ulm, Baden-Wurttemberg
pros: The company allows a lot of interesting technical challenges and technical expertise is very much appreciated by other coworkers. Company pays a good salary.
cons: Significant share of management does have the technical insight nor do they seek advice to make decisions about which approach serves the business goal most. Questionable management skills: It is a common practice within management to assume that every problem in the project plan can be solved by overtime requests.

pros: Nokia is an example of a company that has no problems hiring and keeping the best people. A key component of this success can be attributed to its corporate culture. The company is well known for being employee oriented.  Nokia's employees are taken care of and that has helped it become renowned as one among the top 10 employers in the world.
cons:
No Free Food
Career growth is dependant on Line Manager and not on performance
Remuneration is below industry standard

pros:
- fairly relaxed work environment
- a good place to get in contact with new technologies, different people and cultures, interesting projects
- some good benefits 
- flexible management - generally lower ranks have no problem challenging higher local management decisions
cons:
- salary is below the market average and not reflecting competence or workload
- no reward system for good employees 
- no visible actions against lazy or toxic ones 
- no career advancement path 
- no knowledge enhancement plan - most of the time, to improve one needs to start dodging work tasks and do self study
- we always end up in a big mess every year after huge organizational changes

review_title: Nokia is one of the best places I've worked!
job_title: Configuration Analyst in San Diego, CA
pros:
The people are great and it's a very flexible place to work.
Employees become great friends.
Endless learning and training programs available to all employees.
A corporate benefits package that is unmatched by other companies in the same industry.
cons:
Long work hours, especially leading up to product launches.
Internal department transfers can be long and difficult
Annual raises barely meet inflation/cost of living increases.
Career advancement is not supported well.
Because of it's very flat oranization structure, mid-level managers stay in their current positions for a long time. Nokia is not a place for "corporate ladder climbers".

review_title: NSN is an average company to work for.
pros: You get an opportunity to learn a lot and HR policies are good. Also, the culture and values propagated are in direct connection with the business strategy which help in getting a clear picture of what is required of an employee.
cons: The support from senior management is not adequate and though the HR policies are good but they are not implemented well. Moreover, the work environment is not very good and there is a lot of politics being played out.

review_title: The MOST SECURED JOB & FUN @ Workplace is @ Nokia
job_title: SCM Build & Release Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
i have worked for more than 2.5 years as FTE @ Nokia, Bangalore.

1) ultimate job security that according to me i haven't seen any where.
2) loads of internal trainings to hone your technical/soft skills.
3) working with some of brilliant minds in the industry.
4) Avg . pay
5)Good facilities in terms of transport, workplace..etc
6) Lots of chances for internal mobility.
7) Loads of tech stuff to learn
8) Flex timings
9) Work life balance
10) HR policies excellent !
cons:
1) Not a paymaster / very good salary centre.
2) Food NOT gud.
3) Some politics here n there.
4) limited WFH option.

review_title: Great Place that Values Its People
pros: Nokia was a great place to work. I felt valued and appreciated. Even though my position was eliminated in the reorganization, I felt that Nokia really valued my contributions and did its best to ensure that I had a path forward.
cons:
Company structure was such that efforts would often get duplicated across multiple teams. I think the company has made significant progress to remedy this though.
At the time, focus was too much on short term revenues and not sufficiently on longer-term trends.

pros:
innovative, collaboration,  open, change, chance
We adhere to the highest ethical business standards as we create technology with social purpose, quality and integrity. Nokia is enabling the infrastructure for 5G and the Internet of Things to transform the human experience.
cons: The salary is a little bit less than internet company's, for internet company develops so faster, the hot points are coming and could last for a long time.

pros: Technically very interesting work. Some supervisor are good.
cons: Fair amount of hostility towards women with technical degree in Nokia Networks and Solutions in Finland.  Women face lot of bullying and discrimination in several organizations. Interesting work and important positions given to men, abilities and achievements don't count. Work is taken away even when results are excellent or women are given minor routine, too easy work or they need to invent their own work, while men are immediately given interesting clear work. Work evaluations which lead to promotions are unfair.  Complaining results in retaliation.

review_title: Good job opportunity, but not the company to build a career at.
pros:
-Good international work opportunities/exposure.
-Benefits are middle of the road. (Insurance rate is good, but no 401k match)
-Local (US based) management is willing to support employees as much as they can and will put in the work to get the job done
cons:
-Bad company culture, hard to say many employees enjoy coming to work everyday.
-Engineering quality is not a priority to management. Only schedule and cost.
-A lot of reviews mention good work life balance, this is not true for technical positions. Be prepared to work extra hours and weekends. 
-Constant fear of layoffs within the workforce

review_title: Good for people who are at end of career to rest and relax
pros:
Excellent work life balance
 Pay very high packages for employees above JG 9
 Work from home
 Flexible work timings
cons:
Not good for begineers and people who are young.. you would get relaxed in life which is not good for professionals below 10years of exp
Not transperent abt employee package hidden components
within same team and position their is huge 
 Should never work as a external employee for this org..u dont know when u will be asked to move out

pros: Good colleagues (front line), Technically sound staff, offers decent work life balance. Mid level managers genuinely care about their teams.
cons: The ethics and decision making of Sr. Management and HR are very questionable. The combination of the two companies have created more disconnects and mis trust than continuity or synergy.  Lots of politics and click-ish behavior throughout all levels.  Lack of success and business has amplified these issues to another level.  Reversing these issues will be unlikely without a complete overhaul of Sr. and Executive level Management in my view.

pros:
* Awesome people, both technical, project managers, and leaders
* Good collaboration on projects, across teams
* Diverse culture with a global footprint
* Environmentally friendly
cons:
* Inconsistent leadership
* High contractor ratio to permanent staff
* No where near enough investment in R&D, which will have long term consequences
* Lack of consistent long term vision = pessimistic outlook

job_title: Principal Software Engineer in Cambridge, MA
pros: Amazing European culture, benefits, great offices in Cambridge and Burlington, generous 401K plan. Smart, professional employees.
cons: Too many changes. Looses in the market due to lack of vision and commitment. Focuses more on saving money rather than winning in the market.

pros: The current Nokia is much more focused, has now in-sourced staff in important divisions + the coming closing of the purchase of Alcatel Lucent would make the company much more bigger in size, talents, technical know-how and market share that can compete in major markets (US, China, Europe)
cons: I don't see any yet. I've been collaborating with Nokia under Tieto for almost 3 years and we got insourced by Nokia which is a good thing.

review_title: A better company than all 30 companies I know
job_title: Corporate Communications Specialist in Manila, Manila
pros: Very good medical benefits. Room for career advancement. People who appreciate your work. A boss who encourages you to grow. A work space that allows for creative thinking. Work-life balance. Good and talented people to work with. Management who listens to the employee body. A company that champions innovation, education, and improvement.
cons: Some employees liked to be spoon-fed and are never contented with all the great things the company offers --- this results in negativity-spreading. Salary for some is not that competitive.

pros:
Working on a multicultural environment is challenging and exciting.
Internal mobility gives the opportunity to take it on a new professional route.
The possibility to work with new/latest technologies keeps me alert and drives away monotony.
cons:
Too many company architectural changes which generates uncertainty waves and disturbs departments operational activity as well.
Normal working process is affected as some departments are dissolved and responsibilities inappropriately distributed.
Know how transfer inappropriately done or absent which leads to loss of intellectual property.

review_title: Worst place for your career. Best place to retire
job_title: Software Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: You can find  a team and get lost, doing nothing, working from home. So practically they pay you to exists.
cons:
If you want a real career, avoid this old company:
- Lack of innovation, so you will work on old Systems and procedures.
- The longer you stay, the less you know. So you have the risk to get stuck
- Salary way below the industry. Raises of 1% are the typical way to show appreciation for best engineers. 
- Promotions are scarce.
- Moving many units to India.
- Working with too many teams in India (meetings on the AM)
- Company is divided into infinite groups
- Dinosaur cemetery (at least in the US ) .

pros:
I am afraid I can't point out not even a single good aspect for working at Nokia. 
I mean if you want a job in which you can just get laid off, Nokia is the place to go. 
If you want your brain to get deleted go to Nokia :). 
If you are a girl and you like having sexual. fun, you can go to there to promote by charming the sloppy men.
cons:
Your brain gets deleted and jammed. 
Management is straight-up bad, or better said plain bad. Managers are just wannabees, they are not even able to talk, therefore they just have an abusive behavior and language. 
You don't get salary raises. You are just wasting your time/life in that place

job_title: Solutions Architect in New York, NY
pros: Provides flexibility including work from home.  Has very loyal and helpful staff. Access to lots of technical information.
cons: Leadership hypocrisy.  Mediocre technical staff. Lot of work done in low cost centers while customers in US. Poor recognition of talent. Lower salaries. Playing significant catch up to IT companies on Software. Leadership in Hardware gutted due to lack of focus.

review_title: Right place for ppl who want to be domain experts. No Technical advance
pros:
1) Excellent work culture and good work life balance
2) Still many technical people are present
3) Excellent platform, if want to be domain experts
4) Very good, clear management and its structure
cons:
1) Looking for technical expertise, this is not the right place.
2) If staying for more than an year, cant survive in the current market competition
3) Limited projects
4) Not sure what happens after the Nokia & Siemens contract ends in 2013

review_title: NSN is a big, bureaucratic and very european centric company that wants to be agile but can't seem to get moving
pros: lots of technical talent, lots of resources to draw on, good benefits (in US), a nice place to work
cons: You can easily get frustrated by the bureaucracy, internal politics, and ever present european overseers

pros:
Some good people: Finns are proud, considerate people, who are eager to collaborate.
Attempting openness in communication. Trying to have a flat structure.
Quality and reputation of company (hardware). Nobody makes better quality phones.
cons:
-Constant restructuring. You can't accomplish anything if you keep moving the goalposts.
-Political. Lots of people spending most of their time figuring out how to keep their jobs, rather than adding value.
-Incredibly slow to adapt.

review_title: Further drastic headcount reduction expected in high cost countries
pros:
Some job salaries are above industry benchmark, not as a rule.
Flexi time and home office options
on peer to peer level generally good cooperation, especially among engineers (more competition on leadership levels).
cons: Financial outcome not sustainable. Continued net loss. High risk of head count reductions, especially in high cost countries. Significant risk of bankruptcy.

review_title: It's been the place i started my career and am optimistic of successful comeback
pros: Decent HR policies in the Middle East considering the visa hassles especially for KSA. Competent people to work with.
cons: No training or grading mechanisms whatsoever. Management is turning a blind eye to professional growth.Seems to be adopting the Chinese vendor policy of my way or the highway.

review_title: A good place to advance a career and gain valuable skills, but ultimately lacking in needed speed and agility.
job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in Boston, MA
pros: Flexible schedule, good pay, generous 401k match, great teams, and some exciting projects with a tremendous potential audience reach.
cons: The company suffers from excessive red tape, duplication of efforts, too many cooks in the kitchen, and one hand not talking to the other. This slows down the product cycle and ultimately makes the company less competitive.

review_title: Not a great place if a) you are not young and mobile, b) want a management position
pros:
Has good R&D, good product mix, doing well against competition.
One of the best 401K match programs
Good benefits (but they are not cheap)
Encourages personnel  movement between offices, businesses and even countries.
cons:
Annual profit and sales performance are still shaky.
Flat organization, management opportunities are hard to come by.
Even though the company is European based, still considers US salaries too high.
Prefers young employees that have lower salaries and are willing to move anywhere on moments notice (unless, of course, you are from Finland)
Reorganizes constantly. 
Best technical jobs are outside of US.

review_title: Lots of reorgs and Use of old technologies
pros:
- Decent severance package in case if lay off happens.
- Good work-life balance.
cons:
- Use of very old technologies and no visibility in teams / architects / managers to try new stuff available in the market.
- Continuous reorgs and uncertainties. It's always in people's mind that their team may be close or project/product may be sold to some other company.
- Very less innovation.
- Managers like buttering. Those who do that grow fast. Also, lot of politics in the teams.

review_title: A "doing the right thing" kind of company
pros: Nokia is a great company.  They look to develop employees and offer many opportunities for growth and cross functional experiences.  They look to promote from within and treat employees very well.  They reward top performers both financially and with flexibility and autonomy.
cons: Being in the technology industry, the company is impacted by the ups and downs across the industry.  It is an incredibly competitive environment and the company has not been immune to cost cutting and down sizing.  That being said, they are very considerate of employees as human beings when down sizing is necessary.

pros: Great culture - worked 10+ years here, left and re-joined 2 years ago - professional environment cultivating open mindset; ALWAYS respectful. I asked for a change of roles more than once due to private reasons and was offered various alternatives and a very supportive environment. Opportunities to stretch and learn and engage with more and more colleagues with ever different perspectives. Felt like reaching the home harbor when I rejoined and have been enjoying it ever since.
cons: Can be very hectic - is all in good faith but overwhelming. So much seeking consensus that eventually noone wants to make decisions.

job_title: Head of R&D in Ottawa, ON
pros: Company has recently acquired Alcatel-Lucent.  Integration of the companies is going reasonably well.  The new combined company is well positioned to be successful in its business.
cons: Vestiges of the old, slow-moving, bureaucratic, telecom equipment provider still exist.  One-size-fits-all processes that add no value and cost considerable time and money have not yet been killed off in the new company.

pros: Friendly, helpful manager and technical leader. Flexibe working hours, and as an intern, it is really important. I have maganed to finish my school in time while I was working for Nokia for 2 years. During these years, I have learned a lot about new technologies, participated in the designing process and learned how to provide support. I am a bit sad to leave, but I have to seek out for new challanges. (Learn to use English properly is definitely one of them, sorry for my poor knowledge :) )
cons: I can not think about anything.

pros: Nokia is a perfect place to get involved with the technologies of telecommunication. A large variety of products is being developed here. The most important argument i would emphasize is the atmosphere in the workplace. The people here respect each others opinion and work. (There are exceptions everywhere though, but in general...)
cons: Compensation is less then the average on the market. Also to get a more important and better compensated role in the company rarely can be achieved just by doing more of the work.

pros:
* Excellent work culture - informal, driven by a need to reach goals
* Wide range of techology areas to work on in the Telecom Domain
* Competitive salaries and benefits (the benefits at Nokia Bangalore include salaries paid by the 25th of the month, an excellent Company Leased Vehicle Scheme)
cons:
* Frequent  restructuring and reorganisations disturb the peace
* Politics - within the site and between different Nokia sites 
* Company size has grown huge after the merger of Nokia with Siemens, Motorola, and now  with the aquisition of Alcatel Lucent - concerns that this is too big and can lead to  cutting the flab

pros: Usual corpo stuff, nothing really stands out.
cons:
Totally chaotic management, on both C** level and lower.
Politics. Awful lots of politics. 
Low pay.
Old boy network is pushing out enthusiastic skilled people leaving old guys who know and protect each other since 20 years.
Old technologies.
Practically impossible to get fired, hence people who do nothing. Sometimes teams of such people.
Travel and education are blocked most of the time due to cost cutting.
No working code of conduct. Toxic people are not addressed by management.

review_title: Bureaucracy and politics are a company core competency, I'm surprised anything gets shipped.
pros: Good benefits and a pretty liberal PTO policy (two weeks vacation time plus one week PTO, plus two weeks sick time).
cons: Information from upper management isn't shared with line-level employees, so you're constantly hit with crises or policy changes from out of the blue.  There is so much bureaucracy that it takes a minimum of three weeks to close even the simplest of bugs.  There's also so much internal turmoil: reorgs every six months or fewer, constant threat of layoffs.

review_title: Work in different areas and also connection with different area people gives the picture of the company
pros: The best thing is the flexibility to be able to suite the work time with the free time (family). Easy communication with the nearest supperior.
cons: The uncertanity of the company future and also own work due to lack of information of company concept coming from management. Also the quality that is required in different areas compare to the time limit/line is not line with each other.

review_title: Good start for graduates, stable job
pros:
- great place for fresh grads
- trainings and opportunities for self-development - depends on the manager
- not much stress and good work atmosphere - depends on the manager
- big, well-regarded, stable company
cons:
- depends on the project, but usually lots of maintenance work and bug fixing
- dependency on higher management in distant places, many meaningless telecom meetings, and other corpo-like elements
- low salary growth rate

review_title: Nokia try to connect to consumer
pros:
global international setup
human finnish helps
diversity in the company available
work life balance very well
cons:
too much burocrazy
too much lobbying required to act and reach
too much personal marketing required, so people either focus on biz or on marketing - marketing wins eventhough results are not there
poor performance management
not able to read numbers correctly

pros: Nice offices, flexible work environment (home/office).   Expectations for performance are fairly low.
cons:
Expectations for performance are fairly low.   Maybe I've worked in too many small companies but Nokia felt like a retirement home.

The work environment was fairly chaotic, with changes in product priorities and direction seemly happening weekly.   Upper management was in turmoil and the ripples were felt throughout the organization.

Lots of deadwood sitting in cubicles marking their time. As someone else mentioned:  there are frequent re-organizations and layoffs.  The good people leave, the people who can't get jobs elsewhere tend to stay.

review_title: i work as supervisor and coordinator for mobile networks  instillation 2G , 3G and LTE
pros: its very big and international company and have a lot of projects around the worlds so it can give a good experiences and have good opportunity to get promotion
cons: some time there is no stability because of the the nurture of the work based on the project  so some time feel scar once the project going to finished

pros: Nokia had a wonderful culture.  Work-life balance was very good, and colleagues were very supportive and knowledgeable.  Great to work with colleagues in several different countries around the world.  Benefits were above average (100% matching on 401k up to 8%, good medical and dental, etc.).
cons: Could be a little bureaucratic at times (like any large organization). Unfortunately, the phone business did not keep up with Apple and Google.  Consequently, phone business was sold to Microsoft.

review_title: I loved this job until it all changed
pros: Great colleagues; mostly - trustful, competent, supportive Line Managers; fair pay; good benefits; good work-life balance; a lot of opportunities to learn and grow.
cons: Maybe it is always after many years that people suffer that "it's all not as it was before", but to me it changed too much to enjoy: too much cost-saving and staff short-cutting; too complicated approvals process; everything took so long; in tools / IT area - not much innovations. Merged with Siemens, then parted with Siemens, major changes in management, etc., etc. I just got tired. But I loved it there for 7.5 years.

pros: Very popular product in a product space growing in demand.
cons:
Mid-term risk of site closure. In process of moving current software and system responsibility to remote sites.
High R&D attrition, loss of senior members
Software development done across four countries. Cross site teams working on same components to implement different features simultaneously.
Feature delivery timelines set by sales team customer commitments without R&D input of feasibility and effort.
Uncompetitive pay and benefits

Overall, high level of senior leadership disagreement on short and medium term strategy, nor can follow through with implementation when decisions are made. Cross site politics issues.

review_title: Company with best culture and personal development posibility
job_title: Systems Program Owner in Hangzhou, Zhejiang
pros:
- Has excellent company culture: respect: trust and respect based culture provide flexibility of your working time to balance work & life. You are juded by get work done/done well, not long working hours.  Employee are more inspired instead of controled to get the work done.
- Really focus on people development, believe talents make the differences, employees are invested by different level of trainings and development chances
- Enough challenges provided if talents need a push to achive further.
- Female have equal opportunities as male in the company even in R&D sites
cons: Too many merges happen recent years

review_title: Work is OK, but stressful environment due to constant downsizing
pros: Willing to think outside the box and a drive for innovation.  Ability to influence what you work on.
cons: Management is expected to know everything so some micromanaging can occur.  Everyone is out to make themselves look as good as possible.  Silo mentality which makes it difficult to built solutions across  teams.

review_title: Good company to start, and to follow a management career!
pros:
- Good company to start a career as it accepts people without experience easily and trusts in the learning on the job method
- Easily to switch between career paths, between technical roles or even from technical to management roles
- Good Health Insurance  and Life Insurance paid by the company
cons:
- salary of technical roles tend to do not have any meaningful progression
- you are more rewarded in terms of salary if you exit the company and you come back 1-2 years later that if you stay in the company those same years

review_title: A honest feedback for the external people
job_title: Mitarbeiter Vertrieb und Projektierung / Entwicklung in Timişoara
pros:
Medium salary, a long list of benefits, easy to migrate internally, luxury offices and FLEXIBILITY. 

I manage my time, as long as I do my job no one is following when I come and go. That is partially because I work 24/7, however depends on the department and who is the manager. There are other teams also allowing the employees to organize themselves to work from home as much as they need.

There is no other big company in town  offering this TIME advantage.
cons: I really have nothing to complain. And no one put me to write this. :)

review_title: Nokia is an awesome place to work!
job_title: User Interface Designer in San Diego, CA
pros: Nokia has a great environment to work in. Almost everyone I work with is friendly and professional, and UI Design and Usability has a high importance in the company, so unlike other companies, I am able to just do my job without having to fight politics and SW deadlines to push the better user experience. Since we're a global company (headquartered in Finland), there are lots of opportunities to travel internationally. This also means that we have employees here in San Diego from all over the world, so you get to learn about a lot of different cultures, which I think helps with the fact that there is very little discrimination in regards to gender, age, race, etc. And I'm a FEMALE saying this! Bonuses can be quite large, and few companies can really beat the benefits package offered here in regards to 401K (matches 8%), healthcare (PPO for very little), as well as vacation time (2 weeks to start plus 2 days for every year your with the company). Other than "crunch time", 40 hours a week really means 40 hours a week. And, you get to play with all kinds of cool phones up to a year before they hit the market.
cons: Well, working for a mobile phone company in general, means that there is a very, very long development cycle for products. Its usually more than a year from the time you start working on the software until it actually hits stores. And because of that, Nokia seems to be lagging behind others in the areas of innovation. As far as salary goes, the number isn't as high as it is at other companies, and raises are usually pretty small. I feel like that isn't as important as the benefits package, but not everyone feels that way. If you're looking for a high-paying salary, you won't find it here

pros: Nokia is great to their employees in most cases.  They respect the work/life balance more than any other company I have had the privileged to work with.  They have excellent programs and benefits.  Fitness room, Cafeteria, social clubs and training are all available.  Healthcare and extended Dental are generous.
cons: There have been a lot of changes, these changes seem to be reactionary at best.  Aren't we all in need of a visionary?  Well good luck Nokia I wish you well.

review_title: Relaxed place to work in but bad management
pros: Not too busy with the job. Work athmosphere is relaxed and friendly. Quite much freedom how to complete tasks.
cons: Work was many times meaningless. Why to put effort if results were wasted. Management didn't understand what they want to create. Managers spent lot of money for their own good, for example business trips without any agenda. Managers didn't have any competence.

review_title: Great place to start your career and great place to end it...
pros:
+ you can grow if you have the determination and skills.
+ lot of opportunities
+ less competition as mostly people in large teams do not stretch
cons:
- Salary at lower levels may be non-competitive
- Very top down driven company - no / little value for opinions
- After the recent Reorgs company believed too much in statistics and very less in honest feedbacs
- L4 is overworked and L3 relaxes

review_title: I enjoy working at Nokia Networks.
pros:
Respect, Values, Career growth, Mobility, Trust, Leadership.
Nokia is becoming the same company which it was before merger with Siemens. 
It may take a little a while but it has improved a lot already.
cons: Accountability is still missing at some levels. Despite of data available, it is taking time in bringing same salary structure across the organization. The company still need to identify potential team members who can deliver good for the company and replace with those who are just not working in the right direction.

job_title: Project Manager in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: Great access / visibility to many state of the art technologies, getting to see amazing things being built, usually very good environment to work in. In many teams, good team spirit. Work life balance easy to manage, if you just cared to pay attention.
cons: Big ships turn slowly. Sometimes people were unable to resolve conflicting opinions producing stalls, or ending up going back and forth with decisions. Not a very good environment for career path development because there were just too many people in there. Not very competitive salaries.

review_title: My experience has been good with Nokia, although I preferred when the company was Lucent Technologies
job_title: Senior Manager in Murray Hill, NJ
pros: Technical work is challenging; people are great to work with; get to work with teammates in Europe on a daily basis.
cons: Over the past 7 or 8 years there have been a lot of internal reorganizations with some people being placed in groups where they don’t belong. They need to hire some young talent.

pros:
- Cutting edge technology development
- Extremely relaxed work environment
- Good facilities at workplace
- Latest and the most up to date engineering tools
- Least amount of unnecessary work (You don't need to do all sorts of unnecessary and unrelated trainings and fill boring time consuming forms which are not related to your job function!)
- Focus on what you've accomplished rather than how many hours you're present at work. 
- Can do attitude and faith in workers and the company from management.
cons: - Uncertainties in structure and the future of the company (Because it's working on cutting edge technology, this is somewhat expected!)

review_title: Good company with solid products and services portfolio, emerging software business
job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Dallas, TX
pros:
Global multinational working environment
Cutting edge 5G technologies
Bell Laboratories
Diverse product portfolio
Emerging software business
Flexible work, good work/life balance (depending on manager)
Challenging projects
Online training offerings
The current CEO (Rajeev Suri) is well respected within the company and in the industry
cons:
Personal career growth opportunities
Competitive salaries
Limited travel opportunities
Most decision makers are in Europe and it is a challenge to get visibility and exposure if working from North America office locations

review_title: Satisfying and very creative place to work in.
pros: Got a chance to work with highly talented people, including senior managers and bright engineers. Only wish that senior management listened to feedback from engineers on a regular basis. A great place with lot of emphasis on work-life balance !
cons: Senior Management not very open to suggestions and feedback from lower layers. A company which traditionaly in not open to taking risks.

pros: Overall fantastic culture and colleagues. Very relaxed and supportive environment. Quite diversified. Nice work environment. Tehya re trying to do their best in very challenging times to find ways to support employees. Good 401k match
cons: Bleeding people right now. Significant budget cuts. Many organizational changes, leading to low morale. Terrible healthcare coverage which will probably get worse in 2013. Poor vacation day allotment. Not clear what the future will hold for the company. Mixed messages about future prospects depending on the business unit.

pros:
- Great possibilities to change jobs and career direction
- Going through a (positive) transition
- Possibilities for self-development
- Respects employees
cons:
- Too much HR hassle and bureaucracy at times
- Entry wages are not so great, even though Nokia claims that they represent the area average
- If you're stuck with a bad line manager, that may be harmful for your bonuses & wages. Although this applies to just about every company out there...

review_title: Old platform burnt and sunk, new one let afloat, but not exactly cruising.
pros:
(This was before 2011 when I quit my position at Nokia)
-> Excellent facilities.
-> Good travel and HR policies.
-> Good place to learn programming methodologies.
cons:
-> Lack of market foresight brought about an end to the Symbian platform based phones.
-> Took a long time for the management to realize the reality.
-> Unwillingness to change and change quickly hurt the company.
-> Way too many employees.

pros: A great place to work! Really enjoy. You will learn a lot here. Nokia is really investing on employees. Flexible working hours, respect people, great company culture, very lay back culture, not much politics as many other companies, we are working hard but at a manageable pace.
cons: The stock is way under valued. The company is so big, sometimes that you feel that there are so many areas are not connected well.

review_title: Good experience but too much strategy change
pros:
Nokia is a big compagny well structured. 
Good peaple who have the will to do good job
Possibility to work in remote place (at home) 2 days (even more) a week.
Flexibility in working hour
cons:
Not enough employee training
Strategy change too much, what is right today will be bad tomorrow and should immediately stopped even if long investiment and effort are done 
too much difficulty to evolve and to change position within the compagny

pros: Company values and culture absolutely outstanding!  Individual contributors groomed to become managers who are, in turn, groomed to become managers and ultimately leaders.  Individuals are given great authority coupled with great responsibility.  You are allowed to make decisions - but held accountable for them.   Salary and benefits are comparable to any top company. Goals are clear and achievable.
cons: Company is not financially stable, but is making headway to achieving this end through the selling of cellular business to MSFT.

review_title: overall, a very positive experience, I had the chance to learn a lot and improve as a professional in many aspects
pros:
- well structured company with lots of tools and procedures
- high standard of treatment
- high level of investment in formation of personnel
cons:
- poor communication of objectives from top management
- organisational structure too "dispersed" (lots of super-regional and super-national organisational layers), with the risk for the employee of feeling detached from the company
- local company has been downsized due to prioritisation of other world regions and/or business sectors

pros: Nokia provides a technically challenging work environment. The engineering staff is located internationally and is top-notch. Benefits are good. I really like working there.
cons: There have been a lot of layoffs over the last couple of years, especially among US employees. There is a real short-term mentality. The solution to every problem seems to be to lay people off.

pros: None. Benefits were (past tense) great, as was final salary pension scheme, but these have all gone and, combined with low base salaries make for a poor compensation package
cons: Incompetent management. Nepotism/cronyism Bullying. Poor rewards. Poor procedures and poor quality training materials make it impossible to work. Middle management interpretation of service delivery is laughable and self-serving. Engineers are overworked and expected to be available 24/7/365 to compensate for delayed, overrunning projects that are poorly planned due to management imposed time/budgetary pressures.

pros: I enjoyed the work I did. I found it challenging and rewarding. I liked the people that I worked and the the customers . I have connected with most of these people. The company changed over the years from Lucent Technologies to Alcatel-Lucent then again to Nokia. I've seen the company change focus with management changes. The story is still unfolding.
cons:
-improve marketing
-work/life balance issues
-employees are disconnected from upper management and not made aware of organizational information in a timely manner. Rumors are rampant.

review_title: DV engineer told: My point of view on Nokia
cons:
1> sometimes , people work with at low efficiency 
2> there is not enough alert with market share losing, especially when facing strong competitor
3> Nokia's product line is sole, i think it is dangerous
4> Nokia's salary is not so competitive

review_title: proud of being Nokian, and grateful to grow with Nokia
pros:
1. well work-life balance, don't need to work overtime, and care for wellbeing
2. grow with Nokia, offered chances for continous learning and development, covering various topics from telecomm knowledge, to soft skills like project management, working with efficiency, IT skills, etc.
3. well reputation, as a renowned tech giant.
4. great culture: the values of Nokia are respect, achievement, renewal and challenge. also product quality is highly valued.
cons:
1. less competitve salary compared to rivals, and other companies in ICT industry.
2. under transition dramastically in recent months, and the decision making and communication is not transparent.

pros: We have a great future with 5G and we have a winning hand. The company has operated in various industries over the past 150 years. It was founded as a pulp mill and had long been associated with rubber and cables, but since the 1990s has focused on large-scale telecommunications infrastructures, technology development, and licensing. Nokia is a major contributor to the mobile telephony industry, having assisted in the development of the GSM, 3G and LTE standards (and currently in 5G), and was once the largest worldwide vendor of mobile phones and smartphones.
cons: Need to continue to work hard.

review_title: Good company at heart, but the amount of middle management is like a dragging anchor.
pros:
Good benefits with health care (on site medical clinics), Performance shares, bonus (18.5% THEORY), car allowance, home working, free home office internet connection, good vacation allowance and free phones :)

Excellent work/life balance in Finland, although this is changing, pressure to work longer is increasing
Month off in summer (4 weeks)

Good career opportunities, interesting work, networking get things done!

Possibility to move sideways to new areas to take on new challenges. Opportunity to move to locations around the world.

Multicultural teams, you really get to know how to work with different cultures (although management style is Finnish :)
cons:
People are caring less about the company. Too many failed promises and personal level disappointments. See the media for the walkouts last year in Finland. Morale is low, productivity is decreasing.

As the company shuts down in July (holidays) we employ students to make it look like there are people still working in the office :)
More and more external/temporary workers, who are later employed with tiny salaries.

Bonus tied to company success. If the company does bad, no bonus (€2bn profit in a quarter can still be classed as bad apparently) Company does well, small bonus as the "complex and hidden" calculation method spits out small numbers...maybe there is a mistake in the code ;)

Large. A lot of re-organizations, a lot of middle managers

TOO MANY managers with teams of 3 or less people. There is absolutely no point in this. In some groups there are 70% managers!!! That leaves 3 people doing, with 7 people telling them what and when.

SLOW decisions, SAFE decisions. 

Innovation is touted, but we focus on non value added technology, rather than focusing on enhancing the total user experience (Fastest 3g download, but clunky browser, 5mp camera, but take too long to start up etc etc) We have no idea of the total user experience, as its split into 15 different teams with 15 different managers with 15 different personal incentive targets.

People live by the IIP (Individual incentive plan) "its not in my IIP so I cant work on it" is pretty common. 

Reports. Because the company structure is so flat, with networking the way to get things done, you end up dotted line reporting to a lot of people. You are always trying to persuade people to do work for you as the do-ers are in other teams!!

review_title: Nokia - Great place to work as long as you're on the international (non-US) team
pros: The international teams are the best reasons to work for Nokia.  They are the ones with the most budget, thus power, to work on innovative and exciting products and programs.
cons: The U.S. leadership team is weak;  The CMO, Craig Coffey, is not honest and open enough about the changes in the organization.  There have been many layoffs and the re-organization of employees was handled due to their popularity with the leadership team vs. their work performance or competencies.

pros: Nokia balances well a conservative business approach against the need for progressive product development.  The pay and benefits were second to none for me as well as job flexibility.  The opportunity to learn is tremendous, and there is a great emphasis on further education.  The work atmosphere was mostly invigorating.
cons: There are too many disconnects inside the organization.  Much of this is due to Nokia's constant reinvention.  The corporate floor is perpetually shifting underfoot, so many necessary long-term projects are never completed.  People hold dear to strategic info that would benefit others in order to protect their turf.  In many cases executive management fails to trust subject matter experts and administrators, who usually know what's needed to correct problems.  Recent layoffs are poorly planned and conducted, with many of those subject matter experts summarily dismissed with no concern whatsoever for the resulting catastrophic disruption.  Not enough resources are provided to the efforts necessary to carry the company forward.  Sometimes Nokia is too conservative, especially in mature markets like the US.  Often some high-level communications come across as lies when they conflict with other known info or eventual results.  All of this is damaging morale.

review_title: Needs to improve a lot to survive
pros:
Good work life balance, work pressure is less.
Some of the perks given are good, but these are fast vanishing with time.
cons:
No job security. You are forced to look for a new team to keep your job every 6 months.
You will go nowhere in your career. 
Too slow to react to changes.
Many people doing the same thing without knowledge of what is happening in the other parts of the organistation.

pros:
* Good employee benefits
* Work culture is great. Work environment is nice
* Company promotes a proper work/life balance. 
* Cares for the society and environment
cons:
* Growth opportunity is limited to some extent
* Nokia as a whole has lot of good talents which are not used properly. If channeled properly can get excellent output

review_title: Not the best, but slightly above average
pros: Good place to work. Great mentoring of newly hired engineers, but confusing amount of paperwork one has to deal with even after staying for 1 year. Would recommend as a starting place but not for mid-career engineer
cons: As explained above, the paperwork can get you down, and if you are not pro-active and seek out people who know stuff better, can easily get frustrated by small detail

job_title: R & D Test Engineer in Bangalore
pros:
Nokia is a excellent place to work. 
1. Best place to work.
2. Work life balance is excellent.. no constraint of staying more hours.
3. compensation is very competitive. Even if you have less salary they will offer to match their standard.
4. Management people are very good to access and friendly.
cons: It happens in every company that one or the other suffer due to project tasks/timeline and management pressure.. but it is very rare in Nokia till now.

review_title: I had big expectations and belief to this company, but my belief fainted over the last three years.
job_title: Human Resources Business Partner in Espoo
pros:
I have had really nice and sweet managers (3 in three years) everybody is really nice, but as they have been middle managers with too little power, I assume their possibilities and willingness to manage the subordinants careers has been limited.

Freedom an worklife balance are OK. Working hours are not counted, but the finnish 37,5 hour work week affects so that Nokia House is empty by 4 pm every day. I don't believe this is a good thing from the business side, but you stress levels are in your own hands. Also you can havea remote access to the office any time ad work from home when you wish.

Nokia has invested alot in to new communication measures last year. The internal social media applications are really good (minority contributes, but good anyway).

In average the mindset of the workforce is quite flexible and open!

As a top talent it is easy to gain more salary and education.
cons:
Many managers are promoted when they have shown enough loyalty to the company; this is why many of them don't have best skills to be team leaders or change management skills. I have understood in the end they are like puppets to the big guys above them.

The most disturbing behavioural phenomenon in the organizational culture seems to be "Plenty of buzz and talk, resources first, but then even big projects can be buried in a silence.  
Nokia has not yet managed to have performance driven culture, as not just the performance reviews, but also tasks and projects are shared not so fairly.

Talent management is poor. it mainly concentrates in the top guys in the director positions and to those once got the positive stigma "top talent". Top talent rating is hard to get, and the rating is kept secret even from the top talent him self. Many top talent loose the motivation, or are promoted too fast. On the otherside there are many talented people left frustrated.
 
Plenty of tabous in the organization. Different people are not really allowed and different thinking dies quickly.

Seem to be that the true power is in hand of few, how have been in the company since the 90's. 
Everybody seems nice, but you don't really know whattey are thinking, or are they just staying in the company because during the good Nokia years they got such a good salary they couldn't get the same anywhere else?

review_title: Good work culture, slow to change, missed important "windows of opportunities"
pros: Good work culture, decent benefits (though not par with industry standards), opportunity to work in great products. Great brand name. Had opportunity to work with great, talented people.
cons: HR needs improvement (faced bad experience during exit). Slow decision making. Too cautious resulting in late, often wrong decisions.

review_title: A great work environment that offers competative pay and benefits but not much room for career growth.
pros: The work environment is very flexible, there are also work from home days that can be agreed.  Salary and benefits are very competative.
cons: IT has just recently been outsourced so there are limited career options here in that field.  The company is still struggling with profitability so there may be future headcount reductions in the future.

pros:
Work life balance
Flexibility timings 
Decent pay and compensation
One of the key players in the telecom domain
Absolute scope for learning and automation for testing team people.
There is a good learning scope inside the team and encouragement from the senior management.
Scope given for innovation and key ideas to bring about positive change in the work environment.
system was open to change to some extent
cons:
Changing the role inside the department is hell,
Monotonous sometimes, which someone generally gets frustrated to work with.
So far there was no solution regarding the same.

review_title: A lesson on how not to compete in the tech world
job_title: Software Test Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work life balance. There are so few tech companies (particularly global corporations) that care enough about their employees home life as to encourage weekends off.  401K matching was terrific as well and the medical/dental benefits were top rate until the last year. Working with the latest in wireless technologies, software and test equipment.   Great co-workers whom not only know and ply their trade effectively but couldn't care less about office politics..
cons: Decisions by upper management and executives... yes, this is gripe often heard in the corporate world. However, when you go from one "burning platform" and jump head long into another "burning platform" (ie Windows Phone) it became a more steady decline.  The Metro UI of Windows 7 and 8 is unique, but hardly a favorite among mobile phone users. The early death of the Microsoft Kin mobile phone should have rang alarm bells.... not to mention the fact that Windows 7 devices couldn't be upgraded to 8, and the lack of apps (which should have been tackled early on)..

pros:
- Great work-life Balance.
- No micromanagement.
- Objective oriented.
- Good health benefits.
cons:
- No local Human Resources.
-  Career growth is almost impossible, positions are usually taken from expats and locals not even considered for interviews.
- Lot of talent already gone due to unfair compensations, some managers are taking a constant look to this and others doing nothing with their employees creating bad atmosphere  among peers.
- Focus on customer is getting lost, lot of internal admin stuff reducing time to get proper focus on customer.

review_title: Not a bad place for 10 plus years
job_title: Program Quality Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Great benefits, like paid tuition, and tining for those that need it in thier jobs. Wonderful people and team culture makes it easy to come to work.
cons: Things move too slowly,  we locked ourselves into  Windows phone for 5 years, and further depleted our Market share so much that MS bought Nokia for pennies on the dollar.

review_title: Innovation powerhouse in a tough business environment
pros: Although the economic and competitive environment has been difficult for the past decades, Nokia has kept investing in innovation. Working in a global company is often challenging, rewarding and fun. You get the opportunity to travel around the word, and meet with customers and colleagues in different cultures.
cons: In a telecoms industry that is in constant transformation, the roadmap to the future is often curvy and bumpy. Strategic  redirections, organizational changes, headcount reductions, ... may always be around the corner.

pros: Nokia offers innovative engineering, at cutting edge of technology, employing an enjoyable international mix of people and offering a full spectrum of career opportunities. The offices are greatly located in the center of Antwerp. Nokia has a very interesting venture also : Nuage Networks.
cons: The company could probably do a better job at being in the broader news about the technologies and activities it is embracing and being successful at.

pros: While still an undergraduate, working in Nokia made a huge different regarding the mentality that exists in a multinational company. A great company, with values that are respected both by engineers and upper management, paid overtimes, senior engineers that are always willing to help and engaged to product quality.
cons: For an undergraduate or recent graduate, the starting salary is more than great but eventually, after some years of real hard work, a raise is expected.

review_title: Good benefits but the company is too rigid
job_title: R&D Engineer in Diliman, Quezon City
pros:
Benefits are slightly above the average (i.e. on leaves, HMO, optical allowance, stock discounts, etc.) 
"Flexi Time"-ish setup
Relaxed dress code
Above average pay for fresh grads. But slow pay increase.
cons:
Management doesn't understand or refuses to understand the importance of having legacy systems to have unit tests.
Highly specialized field but the training and support for learning is left unto the employee.
Very lenient on employees with attitude problem.
Too much adherence to "SCRUM" when its not really effective cause of culture here in PH. I think the SCRUM method is developed with the Western culture in mind.

review_title: Mostly good, but some poor management affects quality
pros: Nokia in the UK has some good practices - flexible on going part-time, management that understand life sometimes takes priority over work, and decent benefits. People are generally talented and care.
cons: Lots of drivel from higher management about quality being the focus, but when in comes to practice the quality was falling because basic principles were not being followed consistently across all sites (globally). Cost cutting meant it became harder to do a good job. Constant engagement questionnaires became laughable.

review_title: Think twice if you have other options.
job_title: Hardware Engineer in Mountain View, CA
pros: Nokia's security business is stable and thus layoffs are minimized. Overall Head Office policies are sound. Beautiful campus and a good cafeteria.
cons:
The security business in Mountain View is very poorly managed. The hostile relationship between Nokia (platform supplier) and Checkpoint (application supplier) allowed other companies to win business.
The actual management in that organization is mediocre at best but they are very good at in-fighting especially between the Boston and California branches. Very juvenille.
The company had a lot of issues integrating the security business into their overall business model. The marriage to Enterprise was questionable as there were few, if any, synergies. 
It really looked like a holding ground for people uninterested in challenging themselves.

pros: Smart, nice people and good work-life balance.
cons: Poor executive management prior to appointment of new CEO and abysmal execution.

review_title: Good to learn work but not very good at increments
pros: learning work on live network and getting deep knowledge of GSM only if you are interested. NOKIA tool is also used in various other companies so it will be a added advantage to your resume may be the main highlight of your resume, and however NOKIA SIEMENS itself is a big brand name in the market.
cons: increment is not as good as expected and nowadays only BHARTI AIRTEL and TATA project is big project and hiring is also freezed from a long time only internal transfer are allowed nowadays.

review_title: Great place of work, excellent treatment of people

Fair compensation, and they really put their money where their mouth is regarding values.
Supportive of social activities initiated by site members including a community garden and subsidized offsite events.  Great perks including latest phones.
cons: Glass ceiling for North Americans.  Also just too big so it not only moved too slowly to keep up, but constant re-organizations killed momentum yearly which resulted in massive amounts of wasted energy.

job_title: Retail Account Manager in Buenos Aires
pros: The cutting edge products, the free way of working, innovation level, the possibility of developing and implementing a plan to achieve the objectives, the freedom to express yourself for better results of your dept.
cons:
One of my main challenges was introducing and develop mobile category in Supermarket channel, which had a very bad reputation and experience in previuos years,
Also implementing Category managment in leading retailers,

review_title: OK place to work, in the past
job_title: Senior Testing Engineer in Boca Raton, FL
pros: Most of the people are the best. Most managers I worked for would give you an assignment, tell you when it was expected and then let you go. They were there to help but did not micro-manage.
cons: In 2009 work started to move overseas. The overseas managers did not trust the U.S. workers. In the end development was moved overseas (after we trained the overseas workers) and Boca Raton, FL. site was closed.

pros: Work life balance is good at Nokia. Work from home option varies from team to team. Mainly depends on the line manager. Not extremely stressful. Very flexible work timings.
cons: Less chances to learn new things. There are no experts in specific areas. So, most of the time, issues involve a lot of speculations and guesses rather than root cause identification. Quite a but of office politics. Fewer technical managers which will sometimes impact the employees real bad. Too many managerial roles - so everyone demands updates on all ongoing activities which can get irritating

pros: Decent salary and benefits. Some real smart people to work with who even now are still fighting everyday to help Nokia win in the market place
cons: Arlington Heights campus just isn't valued by senior management. Senior management doesn't recognized talent or innovation, they are blinded by the idea of cheap outsource labor. Very poor Product Management team that can only sell what we don't have.

pros:

- You are working with the latest technology
- Flexible working hours
- Quite nice atmosphere and good culture principles
cons:

- Low pay

review_title: Quick progress for a limited time

review_title: NSN needs to take some drametic measure to turn things around

cons: still have not get out the mess of the merger, lose about 2 years in competetion in the wireless front. the overall response time to the market is too slow.

review_title: Great place to go and grow personally, not so much if you want to climb the ladder
pros: The work life balance - if you want it - is awesome. You will also work with some great people.
cons: Saying that you'll work with lots of not so awesome people. Also the very top seems to lack direction or the ability to convey it.

pros: The benefits are quite good and far beyond what I was offered in previous positions. Time off given is more than fair and volunteering is strongly encouraged as is being eco-friendly and aware.
cons: Management sometimes seems slow to act or acknowledge changing trends within the industry. That make for an environments that always seem to be trying to catch up instead of innovating new solutions.

review_title: Good work culture, but unsure future

cons:
1. Depends on the team, but work is not too technical at least in Bangalore.
2. Too many people are in a comfort zone in the company.
3. Future is uncertain; depends a lot on the success of nokia windows phones.

review_title: Good work culture, difficult internal politics, very good employee benefits
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Mountain View, CA

cons: Very large company, essential advanced technology was hijacked by the group controlling handset development delaying NPI - some decisions by M&A people backfired when it came time to execute at the operating level - just a lot of high level politics

review_title: I had my dream job and then it ended. Looking back, I was not part of the" core business"
pros: Very much customer oriented and solution driven company. From my expereince tried to help out our sales as much as possible from my marketing position I had.
cons: Seemed thet the communication between different business lines was poor. So were the info to the workers from 2nd level and up

pros: Global, large, chances to learn new things  and be on the top of latest technologies/ best practices are everyday life for Nokians. Flexible, supportive management culture, extremely nice colleagues, great benefits, reasonable work-life balance. I loved working for Nokia.
cons: Recent big challenges at the smart phone market changed the atmosphere a lot lately: uncertainty, constant organizational changes and the fact that lot of people were losing their jobs brought negative vibes to work.

review_title: Athmosphere among employees is not good.
pros: International company and global work.
cons: The company still suffers of the migration on Nokia Networks and Siemens Networks. That shows in ill work athmosphere among the employees; people do their best to look good for their superiors, and unfortenately many use all the possible ways to do that; also speak ill, behind back that is, of co-workers, colleagues, superiors, management, other departments etc. Sad, sad, sad.

review_title: My experience in Nokia India is very good
pros: As every body know that Nokia is a brand on own self I feel proud to work in this company.
cons: Some drawback like low understanding between top level and low level management. top level management only follow that type policy like which are doing is right and follow them by the low level management .

review_title: Energetic team, great management, and welcoming envirornment
pros: I joined NSN Hangzhou right after graduation. Worked for 2 years, I was very satisfied with the experience. there were lots of job training, employees take time to conduct code study groups for new comers. They also encourage newcomer to form discussion group to talk about current design and modules. Other trainings also include english training and leading wireless technology development. Work there is busy but fulfilling, hard work gets acknowledged. Senior management communication well and good work life balance. Great place to learn and grow.
cons: Provide more flexible work hours avoid commute time.

review_title: Lousy and shameless politics at its worst in OSS division in Bangalore
pros: If you are in a good group and under a reasonably sane manager , you get to work in very good leading edge technologies in OSS domain
cons:
Oh Boy Where do I start . The Bangalore  centre is the real blot on the company . Don't ever   join this company just by looking at brand  name . The ground reality is very very different .

- Disgustingly slow pace of working .
-Their OSS product is in works for the last god knows many years and still does not see the end of light . The management  does not want to solve the problems they just want to grab the limelight . And they will stoop to any level to achieve the same . 
- Absolute lack of professionalism and ethics .The middle management  in blr  will ruin and  sabotage the programs  because almost all of them are not managers but mere power brokers or power pimps.The health of the project or program, quality of the product does not matter them , all they want is to protect their territory. 
-No HR ....HR is toothless and spineless there .Line manager is the boss there .If you don't massage their egos you would be heading for disaster. 
--Most of the work can done by high school graduates better than the useless old timers  in bangalore .The  work environment is such that you will forget whatever you have learnt all your life within six months of working 
-The result of almost RCA will be management reorg  but the crux of the problem remains because the muck,dirt that is the old timers  remain at the helm of affairs

The list goes on and on ......

review_title: Great work life balance, needs vision
pros: Nokia is a family oriented company. They emphasize work-life balance, green practices, and charity. They have a great 401K matching policy.
cons: Decisions at Nokia seem to be made by democracy, which means that there is no individual accountability for driving things (processes, new products, etc.)  forward, and decisions get stuck in the mill for ages. So long, they miss the market window.

job_title: Service and Solution Customer Analyst Senior in São Paulo, São Paulo
pros:
many great co-workers
optimal working structure
excellent for growth
good to gain experience
great compensation and benefits
training
cons:
no job rotation
much change line managers
IT resources
very bureaucratic
the employee with good working time has no privileges

review_title: Detailed find on the Pros & Cons of working in Nokia Networks
pros:
The company is growing at a rapid pace.
New Customers, More business, New technology & requirements.
No scarcity of work (not applicable for some teams or projects)
No visible difference made between permanent and contract employees.
Cab facility is provided – both to and fro.
Interns/student trainees strength is good and conversion rate from intern to full time employees is also good.
No restrictions on websites.
Wi-fi data can be used in mobiles in campus
Vibrant employees, strength of campus and fresher /lateral hiring is high.
There is no hard and fast rule or too much procedures to be followed….advantage and disadvantages.
cons:
Even though company has celebrated 150 years of its existence, the company is still years behind on many fronts.
No landline or high end desk phones are used on desk which leads to too much dependency on emails, in person discussions and meetings.
The managers and in fact mostly team members are pulled in for in person meetings which effects the productivity heavily.
Teleconferences can be done but the traditional methods of standup meetings and in person meetings are used here.
Mobiles are provided to employees but this is no way a productive substitute for landlines/high end desk phones.
Absolute shortage of meeting rooms with the number of resources double and tripled in past 3 years.
The building facility has not been scaled up in parallel to hiring which leads to lack of place to sit and work.
Meeting rooms and other open areas are converted to ad-hoc temporary work stations.
The initial trainings are not detailed one & it will be a tough task for new joiners who do not any work experience to know how to get the things done.
No directional training provided and too much of self learning is expected.
Too much dependency of manual info.
The system and tool generated information is prone to heavy errors.
The system driven changes also do not get embedded in the system perfectly.
There is no set process followed and this is one of the biggest concern.
Workload is high and even managers are unable to sit and discuss the problems faced by reportees which leads to inability to catch hold of early attrition.
Not using high end desk phones to do the conference calls which reduces the productivity by about 80%. Even mid and small size companies rely on teleconferencing rather than manual meetings.
Wi-Fi strength is reduced as the employee strength is too high for the existing building.
The emails are not responded in time especially by senior managers citing lack of time as the reason. 
Guess the outlook mail service is not required in this company as managers and team heads do not reply on emails… most of the things are verbally or chat confirmed…again traditional method of communication used.
Heavy dependency on manual info as the system generated info is prone to errors.
The team heads or managers do not take an ownership of their own work.

job_title: Global Demand Manager in Irving, TX
pros: If you were fortunate to be with Nokia in the mid to late 90's you were a part of a growing company. There were many opportunities for career advancement. The employee was treated with great dignity and value.
cons: Because you spoiled working for Nokia finding another job that has the same respect for the employee and benefits are hard. It's then that you realize how good the days were in the past.

pros:
Work Life Balance
New techonolgies in some of the RD Departments
cons:

review_title: After 2016 acquisition of Alcatel-Lucent, Treat fALU employee as second class citizen
pros: Interesting technology, great insurance for US employees, lots of vacation, Work from home, friendly people to work with
cons:
Nokia knows how to Screwed its customers --lost US Verizon Market to Samsung 
Product line management teams like to put on shows on new technologies, of which they don't even understood, for example DevOps, IoT, etc.
Frustrating tenure as Nokia depletes US talent base. Every third Thursday is a RIF in North America.

pros:
* Good benefits
* Lots of good coworkers
* Very generous vacation (if you can find time to use it)
* Probably a good place for an internship or co-op.  Some of the college kids working here make as much as some of the full-time employees who have been here for years and have established solid relationships with our customers.
cons:
* Lots of management but no leadership
* Lots of talking but no communication
* The company is extremely siloed, so problems are often tossed over the wall to someone else's silo rather than being fixed.
* The software is developed with no input from the people who actually implement it in production, so time and effort is constantly wasted on both the development side and the implementation side.
* Technology roadmaps are almost purely designed for buzzword compliance.  They look good on the surface, but there is nothing beneath that surface.  Each team is developing in isolation, so the modernization efforts are really about reimplementing the same bad designs with new stacks, rather than fundamentally improving the software portfolio.
* Penny wise and pound foolish in a number of ways
* Very little incentive for experienced people to stay -- raises are tiny and rare, not remotely keeping up with the cost of living.
* Salaries that I'm familiar with are well below average for Austin, even compared to jobs requiring less experience.
* The company is replacing experienced regular employees with interns, co-ops, and ever-cheaper contractors.  Even after the layoffs stopped or, more likely, slowed down, there has been a steady stream of people quitting for better jobs.  A lot of institutional knowledge is already lost, and that trend is likely to continue.
* The only opportunity for career advancement is through attrition, but the entry level management positions aren't turning over much, and they don't pay much more than the positions they supervise, despite doubling the workload.  Most of the management who have left were management from acquired companies who were marginalized by Nokia after the purchase.
* This is a very frustrating time for people in development, services, and operations.  If management has a plan for getting from where we are to where they're telling the market we are, they're failing spectacularly at communicating it to the people responsible for making it a reality.

review_title: Nokia Living off Legacy: externally & internally
job_title: in Farnborough, Hampshire, South East England, England
pros:
Nokia has a great legacy, and I'm proud to be part of that. Nokia is a very strong brand around the world, and work can be very rewarding when the might of the company pushes products and services out the door. Unfortunately, current quality control of products, services and even ideas is lacking. Some employees feel like we're in a downwards spiral. Nokia seems to find comfort in platitudes from consumers/media based on past achievements alone, and overlook the true impact of current shortcomings.

HR-wise, the company is notorious for under-paying. Again, living off a legacy, Nokia seems to think it's prior success warrants a "your-lucky-to-work-with-us-Finns" mentality when in fact many new employees have signed up with Nokia as a secondary alternative to more progressive and quality-oriented companies like Google.
cons:
The general complacency of Senior management and underwhelming of Nokia's current (new) offerings is  most disturbing. Most employees want the company to do better, and constantly express ideas, opinions and points of agitation. But it seems like (apparently bizarre) top-down strategies suppress such cries for sanity or ambition. (Current case-in-point: Nokia wants to win back the US, but refuses to consider Android as a platform.)

In addition to that, Nokia is notorious--at least in the UK--for grossly under-paying. All of that said, I'm still happy I work for Nokia. There are few companies with the reach Nokia has. (I mean that in a metaphorical AND literal sense.) Anyway, it probably wouldn't take too much to convince me to leave if I was offered a position with 'normal' salary and as much potential for impact from a company that had realistic modern-day formulas for success.
