job_title: Software Engineer In Finland in Tampere
pros:
I used to work for the mobile phone unit of Nokia in Finland. I worked for R&D as software engineer. 

The #1 gain for working for Nokia was people I got to work with. They were intelligent, kind, reliable, funny, professional, determined and many other positive things. I keep contact with many of them after leaving the company many years ago and consider some close friends.

The #2 pro was the flexible and supporting organization Nokia used to have. It was easy to transfer from another project, and they tried to fill vacancies internally first. I would not say that career development opportunity was great (it wasn't) but if I wanted to transfer to another project at the same level, this was relatively easy.

#3 pro was the interesting and innovative projects they had. Nokia used to be very innovative and had an eye for future technologies and innovation. The old organization NRC (Nokia Research Center) was a good example of the innovative spirit. The company also strongly encouraged patent (IP) filings.

The rest are not in a particular order: great brand recognition, product visibility (my family and friends used a Nokia phone and talked about it), good training/development opportunities (they had a large number of internal courses and was also generous to offer language courses etc. for foreigners etc.), international career opportunities, sense of security of working for a large, international company .
cons:
The #1 con was the rapid decline of the organization that started in mid 2000, leading to the eventual acquisition of Nokia by Microsoft including the former's personnel. Reorganization and streamlining happened so often with the 'bad news' i.e. another round of lay-off. This demoralized everyone, and everyone was forced to look after him- or herself. Though the company did support internal recruitment, prioritizing these internal candidates under lay-off threat over any other candidates, the turmoil was very damaging to employees' moral and motivation. 

I do think that such a decline can hit any IT company. But Nokia did not handle the difficult time well and it could have handled it much better.

#2 con was the increasing amount of ego and selfish pursuit of one's own goals and needs over the company's that started to become more visible in the early 2000. Nokia hired a great number of young still-in-college engineers during its rising time in late 90's. They were purely fascinated to work for Nokia because they wanted to create great products. They got to work on cutting-edge missions, traveled internationally,  and wanted to become even more successful. Then, something happened: many of the engineers became more political, wanted to pursue their own successes and status even at the cost of the overall success of the company. 

Nokia was practically only viable option for IT professionals who wanted international, "big" careers in Finland. I think that this created the sadly unique disadvantage that too many of the talented but ego-ridden IT professionals saw Nokia as their devise to achieve glory, success, status etc.

#3 con was lack of career progress opportunities. As above, I found it quite easy to get be involved in another interesting project in a similar than current role. However, if I wanted to go for a leadership-path (project managers, project leaders etc.), these coveted roles were generally passed onto someone the hiring manager already knew. If you were an engineer or software architect who wanted to go for that path, it seemed virtually closed for them.

The rest in not a particular order: not pushing people towards excellence but mediocracy, lack of great leadership, mediocre financial compensation, the HQ (Nokia House) is great, but many other offices were not inspiring

cons: Unfortunately the company is moving all of its manufacturing, most the services, delevlopment and so to places like china, portugal, india and poland. Morever the company is more and more externalizing most of its technical expertise.

pros:
Nokia isn't what you could call a high-pressure environment, not least because many first-line functions are outsourced (you could also call this a con). There is some up-to-the-minute technology to work with, and really experienced and intelligent employees. It's a world-wide company with scale of technology to match.
Pay and benefits (at least in my team) are above average, and work-life balance is truly taken seriously here.
cons: Senior (perhaps even middle) management keep making "announcements" which really have little relevance for the average employee, and it goes to show how little they understand about what many people in Nokia actually do. Beyond that there seems to be very little contact between management and staff. Almost all of Nokia's products (with a couple of exceptions) are also seriously behind the market now, and no employee could be proud of what they sell. Much of this stagnation seems to be the result of how difficult it is to actually get a feel for the impact on products of what you do every day. The whole tech thing in Nokia (at least in my team) is "virtual," meaning you never get your hands on anything, instead doing it all at your desk through your laptop. Also it can be incredibly difficult to get two of the multitude of different parts of the company to work together, or even just share a bit of information. This can be incredibly frustrating, and clearly leads to slow implementation of ideas and is probably one reason Nokia is so far behind the game in smartphones.

review_title: Overall the company is still a force and opportunities exist although much more limited than just 5 years ago.
pros: The company is very forward looking. Change is always in the air. The culture allows for mistakes to help build knowledge and learnings. The company has moved to a project focused management style which allows for rapid change in a rapidly changing industry. The benefits and compensation package appears to still be competitive. The environment is comfortable and nice - they spend a lot of money on their faclities to make the employee comfortable and to welcome the customer. The company is still the predominate driver in the wireless industry globally. Aggressively moving to be the leader in wireless products and services as they continue to converge in the marketplace.
cons: Change is always in the air - reorgs happen way too often at all levels.This takes away from focus and progress with in teams. Recent compensation freezes may have put the pay behind the more competitive companies. I could have highly recommended this company 8 years ago but the market has stabilized significantly in many countries and the opportunities for advancement and new challenges are very limited unless relocation to Asia is attractive to you. Has lost some significant opportunities in past years that hurt the company image (flip phone and iPhone to name a couple). The competition has really closed the gap.

review_title: So much promise, but can Nokia rise to the challenge?
job_title: Software Development Manager in Montreal, QC
pros:
Very people oriented, consensus driven company. 
Superb engineering, world-beating technology in so many areas: Nokia created much of what is now taken for granted in modern mobile phones.
Wonderful devices, superb design, incredible reliability.
When challenged, Nokia produces the best phones in the world.
cons: Unfortunately, despite Nokia's incredible advantages, it has made a series of disastrous choices, in large part due to their very "human" culture. Nokia has a very non-confrontational and consensus oriented culture that is slow to assign responsibility or blame. Top management decisions from the late 2000's led to the drastic action over the last couple of years: dumping Symbian, Meego and many thousands of employees. While I don't agree with the current direction, at least Elop did something! Previous leadership simply rearrange deck chairs on the Titanic.

review_title: Used to be a fantastic company with respect for employees. The employees are still their biggest asset
pros: Very smart employees, you learn from each other.  Everyone works together and help each other. Real teamwork experience. Easy to network with people in different locations and countries - valuable network for lifetime. Most people have a can do attitude and people get on with things rather than just talk about it. No politics - lets do it! There is a formal mentoring program where you can get a mentor for your career. I got also informal mentoring through out the years from most of my managers and other senior management which was really valuable. Friendly and easygoing people in general and you feel part of a family. Everyone is hardworking but still the atmosphere is fun. People were trusted and given new challenging opportunities regardless of gender, culture, religion, age etc as long as you did your job and delivered.
cons: The friendly, humane attitude where people were respected and trusted, changed with the new CEO introducing a cold, money based culture, but also spending loads by using an army of external (expensive) consultants instead of company employees. The constant layoffs demonstrated by the new leader have worn people out. Employees have in many cases been first relocated with their families to the other side of the world and then made redundant after a few months. This clearly doesn't indicate very good planning from top management and the consultants used.

review_title: Was a great company to work for at the time
pros: I was working with great people and great technologies, with teams spread across the globe all working towards a common goal.  Good work/life balance, benefits and opportunities for travel available if desired.
cons: As competition grew, the slow pace of change (driven by complacency?) became frustrating - seemed that vision and strategy was driven by too many old-timers who I believe viewed the company as a 'job for life' and couldn't believe that Nokia might be out-passed by the new platforms.

review_title: It was a great company with great people and great goals, but now it is just an average cost obsessive employer.
pros:
- you will work in international company. You will meet lots of new people from different cultures, different areas, it is a great experience to work in such company
- high level of respect and generally very warm attitude from people. Overall atmosphere of the company is "finish" - very calm, very slow, but still - everybody is in positive spirit
- there are still really innovative areas to work if you are technical persons, but note - this company is ruled by managers and HR, it will never be Google/Facebook/Twitter type of innovations.
- in some countries pay is above average in the market, but it is almost impossible to get raise in pay.
- good work-life balance, results matter most - no any control freaks in management
cons:
- this company is ruled by HR and middle management. Top management cannot really push anything innovative if it doesn't please middle management. And forget about any promotion in global if you are not in Finland or Germany.
- Right now due cost control obsessions in most of the countries daily allowance are changed to meal reimbursement. So when you eat you have to keep the ticket and there is a max amount allow. Now hold on to your chair - max daily for Prague 21 eur/day (!!), Munich 28eur/day, Helsinki 45eur/day. It is so disrespectful and it shameful to be an employee and preplan your meals per day, calculate in a restaurant. Now I just prefer not to travel to avoid unnecessary stress with all those tickets, reports and etc. 
- this company tries to be Services company but it is still very far from it. Take a look a customer portal - it is still using technologies from 20th century (like iFrames)

review_title: Nokia after 15 years in the Company
pros:
Personal growth really depends on you, your performance, your spirit and your links inside the company.
Work-life balance is always declared and sponsored. It really depends on each employee to find the right balance and organize the working time. Home Office is possible.
cons:
Company values are to be rebuild for the new Nokia. Management are working in order to maintain those, but at the end of the day the financial performance is the real value of the company.
Training is very low in last years, most of the training is on the job training.

review_title: A great company with low hierarchy and a lot of autonomy
pros: I loved working for Nokia. I found my colleagues friendly and smart, and it was very easy to approach just about anyone in the company. It's too bad that things were so bad financiaaly that a lot of the cool programmes we used to have were stopped, and a lot of people laid off.
cons: This isn't necessarily a con but it's good to know that it's a big place. You have to good with networking to succeed,

pros: Pay and benefits are great and I believe the only reason many stay with the company. Facilities? This is a hard area to describe/measure with tunnel vision.
cons: Cons: no true career development,  unless you know the right people. Do not expect to advance based off merit, dedication and hard work. Some may but appears to be a good ole boy system as is the case with many companies. Any merit increases are few and far between, negotiate well coming in including bonus payout % as well as time off.

review_title: Nokia Global Delivery Center is not a place to be for Technical positions .
pros:
1) Good pay & salary break up
2) Decent infrastructure & perks 
3) Absolutely no work pressure for senior professionals with JG-9 or above.
4) Good work life balance , work from home culture and effort utilization capturing system organization wide .
5) Option of switching b/w roles , business units within organization after 18 months of service.
cons:
Left the company in bare 3 months for the following reasons :
1. Employees seldom complain about too much of work and no play . My experience with Nokia was a bit different in this context ..It is a place of no work and all play ..specially when you are part of GDC India team . This is quite embarrassing situation for person like me who was left with an option to take an unexpected and preterm exit from there .
2. Too many cooks spoil the broth . This saying sets a classic example while working at Nokia ..All PM's, Stream Heads , Sub Stream Heads, Lead Architects,SI - region Head(s) all trying to race with each other one & only simple task - i.e. Estimation of work . The real ground work is often being done by junior engineers and sub contractors made to work like slaves.
3. Recent acquisition of Alcatel announcement by Rajiv has made Nokia introduce a lot many re structuring in the existing set up of organization structure changes and policies and has introduced dirty internal politics . I believe even Leadership team does not have a clear vision of who's doing what in future post Alcatel merging in Nokia ecosystem .
4. Every new morning there is a new policy with GDC overridden by the earlier version . Policy makers themselves have not experienced the facets of day to day challenges and equation of work . To be precise , these policies are related to travel, hiring, PO, training, processes for project execution, project KPI's on Quality & more .
5. No technical engagement for anyone joining as a TPM . Roles & titles have a huge disconnect and falls apart . 
6. Working in the role of a Project Manager you would never interact with your end customer , you will never have any control on project team , no control on project risks & ways to mitigate , project costs and what you are implementing as a solution . Long story short , it is pure pure proxy PM role that you are asked to play without applying your wisdom or cerebrum intellect .

pros: Nokia is an international IT company with really good working conditions and collaborative spirit between the colleagues. Furthermore, as all large companies do, it offers the opportunity of job rotations in case you want to enhance your skills and understand another product.
cons: As a large company, there are too many processes and management levels. Also there are no significant increases in employee's salary throughout the years.

pros: Good company that seems to focus on employees even better than Alcatel-Lucent which they merged with. Good set of processes and push for consistency (with some flexibility). Opportunity to work with great people and a very diverse workforce that spans the globe. Good pay as well. Working from home is allowable.
cons: Tough market with price pressure so always needed to adjust workforce size and product line. Engineering jobs better than support positions as in support goals and guidance can be less clear, thus making accomplishments a little harder to state especially in quantitative terms.

pros:
Hike is good on average
Package is good for new joinees
Have started working on and implementing certain new technologies.
cons:
Work life balance has been seriously impacted throughout the last 1 year
Have to work for long hours each and every day.
There is hardly any entertainment.
Can't take leaves, this is the worst of all.Even though you have lot of mandatory leaves they won't let you take.You have to plan well in advance and have to fight and give hundreds of reasons for even 4 - 5 days leave and that too they might try to cancel at the last moment, they won't understand or care about family problems or your health issue.
Project management is awful. Don't understand any technical stuff and only cares about timelines.They can make your life hell, they will call you at odd hours , they don't care whether you are in hospital or in funeral. They yield more powers than your manager.
Quality of products are degrading because of the workload and the deadlines and the pressure created by the project management to meet them.
If you are working good they will keep on assigning more work to you until I becomes impossible for you to handle.
You won't find a single day where you can relax a bit and sit somewhere for half an hour and have tea or coffee, they will immediately call you.
Work load is increasing as lot of people are leaving and the company is not recruiting experienced people to fill the void.
There is not much benefits for employees, no free cabs or meals or even snacks.
Monetary awards also has been cancelled only certain points based merchandise system is there which is not very useful.
Lot of useless meetings.
Lot of dependency in works but your manager or project managers won't understand this, they expect you to do everything.They expect you to call others wake others from sleep or contact them while they are in emergency and get you unblocked in your work, if you can't do that it's your responsibility.
Lot of companies are offering more package nowadays with much lesser workload.
The management can only consider increasing your pay if you put down your papers,. Otherwise they won't care much about normalising the salaries of old employees with newer recruits, there is a huge difference in salary between them.
Technically incompetent people at certain top posts will commit the delivery dates to the customers without consulting the technical people and without knowing the technical challenges.

pros: The company is in its upward trend and realizing its ambition in mobile world, IoT and wireless connection. With the acquisition of Alu, it has become the NO 1 in LTE market and still see much opportunity in the future in 5G, IoT.

review_title: Good work-life-balance if you are willing to compromise a lot
pros: Good work-life-balance. Home office is possible. Horizontal movement is possible, you can try out yourself in lot of fields. Free parking for all the employees.
cons: Compensation package is below the sector average. Lots of political decisions. No clear goals/the goals changes too frequently. Adhock decision making. Big open-plan office. Service years are more important than the achievemenst.

job_title: Human Resources Director in Helsinki, Southern Finland
pros: Flexible location, good reputation based on former success, a clever engineer / tech development base of employees that could do anything and truly make both money abd the world a better place.
cons: Power struggles and politics sees departments disfigure each other leaving no one capable of delivering great results. A sharp and compelling image has been recycled from the devices days but it masks the true disregard and contempt held for regular employees by management.

pros: Higher salary | No stress while wokring | Good working enviornment | Well designed buildings and nice infrastructure | Free shuttle bus services to various places
cons: Located outside the city which makes difficult to acess| You can be dismissed so easily | Extreme politics at the higher side of the management | Takes a lot of time to process salary related issues

review_title: Comfortable job, just don't expect to climb up/side easily
pros:
Pretty good total compensation 
Good work/life balance
Modern office and good location with myriad of places to eat nearby
cons:
Limited upward mobility, internal job market is a joke (you're stuck)
ALU integration has brought about many layoffs and that is kind of expected but there is just too much secrecy and uncertainty during the whole process
Product documentation and knowledge sharing is nearly non-existent. As a result, employees cling on to useful information as this essentially becomes their net worth in the team

review_title: Good work life balance but poor career development
pros:
Work life balance. No pressure. Respectful colleagues and managers.
Opportunities to develop yourself if you are pro-active.
Large company with very interesting jobs
cons:
You feel like can't  influence or are important for the achievements.
Management see you as a number and not a talent and person.
There is Internal Job Market opportunities but not really working.

job_title: R&D Manager in New York, NY
pros: Nokia is a global technology leader. Here you have chances to work with kinds of talents to change the world. You may change your innovation idea to reality which is attractive to me.
cons: Comparing to the local internet companies, the salary of telecommunication is a little bit lower. And in telcomm industry, Huawei's salary is very high,but the pressure in Huawei is also pretty much higher as I know.

review_title: Great Company Culture with Low Survival Visibility
pros:
- Great company culture, fantastic engagement
- Flexibility to explore ideas 
- Very good platform to build and enhance your existing skills, encourages learning
cons:
- Existence of the organisation is a challenge
- High cost cutting, with low investment in new initiatives
- Atmosphere of fear
- Duplication of roles and responsibilities
- Complex matrix organisation with addition of complex verticalisation in the organisation

review_title: Typical public corporation, with reasonable compensation but with politics in abundance.
pros:
Good package (about industry average), bonus, insurance, gym membership, relatively new cellphone, laptop.
Reasonable office space and location
Flexible schedule
cons:
Some places have a better package.
Reorgs happen too often
Not many opportunities for prof development  and career growth.
Too many management layers, hence - political struggle on every level.
Inefficiency induces extra hours and stress.

review_title: Managed to learn a lot about the telecom sector and experience different markets
pros: Opportunity to focus on interest areas. Culture of respect within the company.
cons: Management focused only on costs and not on innovation. No clear strategy, strategy is more like a vision statement. Poor capabilities of account teams to do solution selling and most accounts can perform only 'box shifting'

pros: Very good professional - personal life balance. Satisfaction that the technology that you work on positively impacts millions of individuals.
cons: At board level, lack of direction to succeed. Not much future prospects in terms of job security as the company is drastically losing market share and value.

pros: Open communication, friendly approach.Flexibility and cleaninless
cons: Constant Changes , No expert support, No punishment and no rewards.Not clear picture of the company's goals and plans for future. Remote management without insight information...etc.etc.

pros: You have the possibility to earn good money. Most of the time you have a really international team. If you want you have the ability to travel.
cons: The work which you are doing is not recognized my the management. There are no individual bonuses. If you have your feedback talk with your boss there is no increase of your salary, even it was really positive.

pros:
They really care about their employees.
Work-life balance is important, and they mean it.
Quality work environment
Great benefits
Innovation is encouraged
cons:
Too much process and paperwork, bogs down progress
Constantly looking to change or re-org too quickly
Too many people who have worked there a long time and therefore know that the current way is the best and only way to do things.

pros: Great people, good benefits, possibilities for horizontal movements.
cons: Talent management seems to be non-existent. Potential talented future leaders not recognized at all. I had to leave in order to finally get a line management position. At NSN, technical specialists become managers and they are not necessarily suited to the position. Too much emphasis on technical skill only, soft skills are ignored. Those with leadership ability but not enough technical expertize don't necesarily have possibilities for career advancement.

pros:
- Very social, very european.
- Decent work/life balance.
- Above average benefits.
- Nice workplace atmosphere.
- HR is generally on your side.
cons:
- Bonuses are paid independent of actual performance.
- There is no consequences for not doing your job.
- Speaking up about competency issues is not appreciated (be nice to everyone policy)
- It's embarrassing to say you work for Nokia, because the portfolio is pathetic.
- Senior management is agnostic to what the company actually produces.
- Every new project is an internal politics game rather than an external market game.

review_title: Treats its employees extremely well, at some cost
pros:
- Great salary / benefits esp holiday/vacation
- "Very Human" company, really cares about employees, particularly those in RIF situations
- Employees empowered / autonomous in their respective areas
cons:
- Too lenient and at times ambivalent toward poor performance at all levels
- Employee programs almost too generous, particularly in tough times
- Classic hubris among management / employees in 2007+ timeframe as the previous market leader, until too late

review_title: A great company to work for in better times
pros: The people were amazing - best group of people I've ever worked with in my life. In addition, Nokia took good care of its people - salaries were decent, benefits were good, and travel opportunities were impressive. There were plenty of opportunities for career development including both upward and lateral moves within the company.
cons: High tech is a very volatile industry and Nokia has steep competition. The lay-offs and management/division restructuring can seriously reduce both your job security and your long-term prospects with the company.

review_title: Not a good experience so far (except only 2 years in between)
job_title: Radio Access Engineer in Cairo, Cairo Governorate
pros: It was a good environment tile 2 years ago, when management was caring about their teams and their competence, not about only themselves for not being laid-off due to the bad environment for terminating almost 17000 employees and it was an environment of full untrust.
cons: Lead in LTE technology as well as WCDMA in Radio.

review_title: A fantastic journey of creating a mobile leader
pros: Never a dull moment, always a lot of changes and new developments in the organization. The journey from 2007 has included a great merger, a very challenging world economy and now a bright outlook with a clear strategy
cons: For many years the investement in people and their development has been seriously challenged, but now things are looking better. There has been very little opportunities for training and development for almost 3 years

review_title: If the telecom environment would not get so much price competition from Asian companies it would be fun to work there
job_title: Head of Business Excellence (reassigned to 902294) in Munich, Bavaria
pros:
- very flexible working hours, possibility of home-office, the results count
- organization supports the development and implemention of new ideas
- good salaries - comparable with market standard
- hirachies do not matter
cons:
- constant focus on cost reduction and profitability improvement impacts motivation
- constant reorganization and new bosses delay promotion
- significant but important decissions are taken too late

review_title: Good company, but no future for USA employees
pros: Good benefits, global leader in telecom, good exposure to different technology and processes, decent training available
cons: No future for USA employees, software quality suffers because global partners don't have good communication with all development teams and huge code churn with no controls, code architecture not designed well

pros: While at Nokia, I had the opportunity to work with and amongst some of the most talented people world-wide. I found a working environment and culture that encouraged me to dig deeper and achieve more than I ever thought possible. Very grateful!
cons: When global sales began to diminish, the thriving environment I'd once known turned a bit grim rather quickly. This is not to disparage Nokia at all. I believe this is a common dynamic in the corporate world.

review_title: Mergers are not great...but looking forward
job_title: Distinguished Member of Technical Staff in Coral Springs, FL
pros: Benefits are pretty good.  Good Medical and Dental plans.
cons: Management focus on costs means that creativity is a bit stifled.  Travel needs to be approved by god so I work closely with people I have never met in person.  It is difficult to stay focused on 3 hour design calls.

pros:
True to their values, NOKIA team members respect each other. 
Opportunity to travel, meet new colleagues+customers, all over the world and participate in big known international projects/companies. 
Continuous formal training opportunities.
cons:
Career progression on the payment side is very slow.
Office location could be closer to public transport. 
Office is over crowded.

pros: It's a great place to work, with great people and leaders. You have the chance to work with people from all around the world and learn form a multicultural environment.
cons: As all big companies, it moves slowly for some important decisions that affect the overall focus of the employees. I would like to see more competitive salaries/ packages.

review_title: A lot of room for improvement !
pros: Homeworking 2 days per week in France
cons:
High level of stress, created by a middle management far away from the real life, and not concerned about the "humanity" of the resources under their management.

Heavy reporting culture, just for the sake of Reporting (not linked with a "vision" or a real need).

Dilution of responsibilities, too many silos, complex organization: lack of ownership and autonomy.

Reduction in Force to come in France - most probably.

review_title: Great Company if you are not concerned much about money
pros:
Great Work Life Balance
Clean Office
Lots of opportunity for promotion and career growth.
Lots of opportunity for training and self improvement.
Allows switching of projects so you can always work on something you are passionate about
Sends people abroad for training
cons:
Very bad salary growth. 
Even if you get promoted you will not be fairly compensated.
Fairly common for people to take on  many roles and position to cut sots but not be compensated for it properly.

pros:
Finnish culture of respect and discussion.
In some departments interesting experience with lean and agile practices.
In LTE the biggest (so far) adoption of Large Scale Scrum (LeSS).
Comparing to the others on the market, quite new programming tools and modern practices.
Stable work, extremely difficult to be fired.
cons:
Lot of merges in past few years.
As a corollary corporate buzzword bingo everywhere.
Lot of politics, difficulties with changes without consulting with too many layers above.

pros: Friendly environment, great culture and you have the opportunity to work in projects using cutting edge technology and open source programs.
cons: As a working student, even if you have considerable tasks you do not have access to privileges like "work from home".  The payment is low for the hours you work and there is no productivity bonus or reward system for the hard workers.

review_title: Working in Nokia is a real life
job_title: Tester, Local Product Owner in Beijing, Beijing
pros:
Working and life are balanced in Nokia. At most, 30 days annual leaves can be applied if you are employed as longer as possible. :). 
Respect value can be reflected in the culture of the company.
cons: Even if you a talent,  your performance have to be balanced within the whole team. So, for everyone, no strong aspiration to do the best for everything. Sometime, OT is must have.

pros:
- Supportive Management Team
- Great HMO Benefits and other perks
- Flexi-time
- Cool and cozy office
- Gym Facilities
- Flat Structure (sort of)
- Any dress will do
- Corporate environment
- Hackathons and Innovation
cons:
- OT depends on which Tribe/Group you will be deployed (unfortunately, my tribe does OT work all the time even in holidays)
- burnout on repetitive work
- slow career growth for aspiring developers
- Average Pay
- High attrition

review_title: Great place to work but with complex organization structure
pros: Salary, working environment and people are great. There are lots opportunities within the company all over the world.
cons: Too many managers in the office and the organization in each department is quite complex. Nobody monitors the performance of the team and lack of feedback.

review_title: Every departments are different so Where I'm working now is grate but I worked for a terrible part aswell
pros:
My team and my colleagues have a very good competence and knowledge. I love to work with them.
We have a good place in the center of the city. the working time is very flexible
cons: The salary is not too good. I haven't got any raise for 3 years. The tasks sometimes good, but sometimes stop before the end of the project and told us ("look guys you will do something else this is over... :(")

review_title: Was an ok company to work for
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Work Flexibility
Strong Portfolio of products and services
Very good training programs for employees
Good potential for growth if they can survive their current situation
Strong presence outside of North America
Fairly generous benefits - especially vacation and sick leave.
cons:
Company in the process of downsizing has put growth on hold
Sometimes feels that no one is steering the ship
Sometimes multiple people driving the same issue with no clear responsibilities.

pros: Good working environment. Nokia has a very strong set of internal values and treats its employees and customers always in the right way. They have traditionally been able to hire some very good people.
cons: In recent years they have lost direction, and were once too proud of themselves to make changes. Too much control from the head office (Finland) has stifled development and innovation.

job_title: Senior Marketing Manager in Irving, TX
pros: Nokia treats you very well.  The company solicits and examines your input for improving the work environment.  Nokia builds solid products that add value to the industry.  I would work for them again without a second thought.
cons: My particular position required about 75% travel.  I was away from home quite a lot.

pros:
-company is focused on making profits
-the plan is on right track
-sold of loss making divisions ,focus is on 4G ,IP etc
-good bonus from last 2013 onwards
cons:
- Horrible culture , 
-some teams are build based on people from same ethinic background - if you are not from same community you will probably remain were you are .
-"0" quality

pros:
Big company, easy to get support on different areas:
- IT support, ergonomics advice, etc

Good opportunities to get training:
- You could propose a training and it was arranged.

Very informal and relaxed working atmosphere.

Lots of employee activities: weekend trips, hobby clubs etc. 
Good benefits.
Flexible working times.

Sometimes it was possible to go to abroad conferences.
cons:
Not easy to get a raise.
Too big R&D machine was becoming too stiff to react. 
- It was impossible to change even little details.

Too much middle managemet.

Top management at that time made strategic errors and crashed the mobile business.

pros:
Flexible timings
Good work life balance
work from home option for 3 days per week, again depends on manager
cons:
Full restructuring and cost cuttings,
No place to sit, fully congested area,  no place in canteen during lunch, 125 ppl occupied in 100 capacity
Most of the managers are not worth full for their positions, no proper performance evaluation,
Dont increases compensation for internal employees
Compensation is almost same for freshers and 6+ years experience employees

review_title: Awesome Place to Work and Work-life Balance
pros:
Lot of new emerging technologies to learn.
Good Variable pay every year (Avg. 125%).
Decent Hike based on year of experience.
Internal Job change for new technology is very easy.
Always Open for new opportunities.
Very good Benefits for their employees based on Job-grade.
cons:
Little pressure at work (same as other companies). If you would know how to handle it. Its very easy.
Due to lot of business merging with other small industries, people of nokia looks job unsecured.

pros: Nokia Research (now Nokia Technologies) was a great place to work, very good freedom to innovate. Absolutely great culture of trust and good support system to try out new initiatives. Very well educated & respectful managers. great set of technologists - creative & fun to work. Making culture & risk talking reverberates. Flexible timings.
cons: Very less market input or understanding of consumers, needs stronger focus on market n software. Many reorgs & some unnecessary meetings.CEO had mostly no clue what was happening and which needed more investment vs less.

pros:
Ambitious goals to become a leading telco vendor
Broad technology base
Global player
People know the Nokia name
cons:
A lot of thier internal processes are confused due to aquiring Alcatel-Lucent and Siemens.
They've made key posistions redundant, leaving responsibility voids.
A lot of former Alcatel-Lucent employees are underpaid.
Former ALU staff in Australia have been trying to have thier EPA updated with new Nokia only to have Nokia try immature heavy handed bargaining tactics to remove benefits.

review_title: Not as good as it could be
pros: A big company in permanent transformation and open to suggestions to improve, with chances of international mobility and constantly challenging. It requires much from you but the reward and satisfaction of the success can be big.
cons: Bad salary in Argentina. Adjustment only once a year and behind the inflation. The sell and pay in USD to customers and vendors, but the salaries are stucked compared to that currency. Constant reduction and increase of headcount.  Big rotation and a company in process of centralization in global pools/hubs

review_title: Good If you want to learn on your own, there is lots of opertinitiues
pros:
1> Good benefits
2> Lot of telented people around the world, who are ready to help and guide
cons:
1> Less skilled managers, who thinks they know lots, but actually doesnt.
2> Not much help from management in career growth

review_title: Telecommunication businees is dynamic business. Nokia Siemens Network is one company that is ready for change.
pros:
They provides work life balance concept and apply to real life. 
We can get an international experience when we travel in business trip on projects. 
They provide an excellence benefits.
cons:
Career path , no stock option provided , many rivals in their market 
Some solution needs 3rd party product to support and cannot control

job_title: Retail Sales Manager in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1) Nokia had a Work Culture, where one could take decisions and get Guidance when required
2) Exciting Work Environment in the developing Telecom Sphere in India
cons:
1) A part of the Top Management preferred On Paper Experience rather than In Market Experience
2) Movements were slow and Career Management was 'Work Under Construction'

review_title: Used to be a nice place to work
pros: There is still some degree of liberty in doing your job. Work life balance can range from OK to excellent, working hours are flexbile and also working location.
cons: There's a strong lack of leadership and vision, the company is lost and has to face competition which is not used to. Restructurations are going forward but they're firing member of staff, some of which are even very bright employees, and leaving in place the very people that are responsible for years of failure.

review_title: Some good and smart people, but overall Nokia suffers from bureaucracy and
pros:
- flexible work schedule i.e. telecommute
- international colleagues
- depending on the role, international exposure and travel
- able to switch teams within the company
- good benefits
cons:
- promotion and hiring not merit-based; based on "who you know" within the company
- poor, and rapidly declining, position within the industry
- unstable and disorganized i.e. reorganization every 6 months
- too much powerpoint
- always talking about strategy, not enough execution!
- average salary

review_title: Will pay you lots of cash, not respect
pros: You will earn a pile of cash if you meet your targets. Not sure if they still pay well, but in those days of market leadership they used to pay really well.
cons: You will not get much of breadth of responsibility. The cross-functional exposure, or the freedom to implement changes / initiatives that you feel are required for the local market, is really limited. As a sales professional you are supposed to follow orders, blinkers on. Moreover, no one higher up will take any cognizance of your market feedback, new product requirements etc. The structure is very formal, very hierarchical.

pros:
1. Very good working culture, majorly derived from the Siemens side.
2. Good and innovative products.
3. Good compensation off-late.
4. Very good work life balance.
5. Good career growth.
6. Good employee specific policies.
cons:
1. Lots of restructuring causing more instability and fear.
2. Bad growth outlook for a long time.
3. Many of the perks are being withdrawn.

pros:
+ robust and well designed technical products
+ good, comfortable office environment (desk, laptop, chairs etc)
+ very technical and strong in terms of Research and Developement
+ dynamic in terms of product and software feature introduction.
cons:
- management: lack of empathy, lack of necessary skillset(soft and technical skills)
- continous gossip between employees undermining company
- management isn't fair towards employees. (always positive towards some employees and always negative to others)
- individualism advocated with great enthusiasm undermines the company

review_title: Super company to work for during the years.
pros: High level of responsibility and high level of freedom on how to accomplish objectives. Has learned a lot over the years which can be used in other contexts as well. -Be it small or large scaled business.
cons: Bureaucracy / too political / too much HR which allows for very little flexibility to be made on an individual level.  / too much consensus driven decision making.

job_title: Senior Business Development Manager in London, England
pros: Great network building. Smart people. Great products and variety of work. Great to leave- ie they treat leaving employees better than current, as measured by their severance packages. Great for references and benefits. In the UK full car allowance plus fuel card!, Great offices, great locations. Great travel perks. Comp quite good.
cons: Super bureaucratic, 3 teams working on competing things to you, doesn't bode for effectively building a company. All the managers manage upwards, not downwards. In denial for so long about the market, led to losing ground and face.

pros:
Good opportunities to attend several trainings and to learn new technologies. 
Good support from your colleagues. 
Company has very good future after buying different companies.
cons:
In large organization you might loose your motive, specially that after hard work for long hours, you are not getting appreciated. 
Sometimes your manager or leader will get compensated for your hard as it was his own work.

review_title: Good place to work but changes are too much
job_title: Senior Project Manager in Hangzhou, Zhejiang
pros:
Good culture and good workmates. Office politics are rare and engineers can focus on real work. However, boundaries among L4 departments provide lots of challenges.
Annual bonus has been really little before but situation is much better since 2012.
cons:
Lots of changes in organisation during recent years, even badges have been changed several times due to company name change (Nokia -> Nokia Siemens Networks -> NSN -> Nokia Networks again)
Salary increase is little to current employees but can increase a lot for a returned employee.

pros: Very good mobility, lots of opportunities to try different roles, whether technology, product management or devOps - there are more opportunities in Wroclaw, the city where I worked - you can work in hardware, software or IT integration
cons: Some difficulty in visibility about HR policies - some regions do not have that good a working environment, specially the Middle East, Africa region

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Rio de Janeiro
pros:
- Company clearly invests in you.
- Training is part of culture
- Flexible hours/home office
- Non hierarchical culture: everyone has a voice, nobody is better than anyone else.
- Employees are generally respected
cons:
- Some deliver bellow average work and do not get penalized. 
- Raises and rare and small. 
- Lots of overtime (flexible, though)
- After the merge with ALU, some of the cultural traces (described in the pros section) are slowly dying.

pros: There are lots of opportunities for learning and growth. There is little politics here and I feel that everyone has a fair chance of getting roles if you are doing a good job.
cons: The work load is very high. There is also high pressure to deliver quickly and with quality. Overtime and weekend work is common.

pros: Nokia values initiatives from its employees by creating an open, transparent, trusted and empowering environment. Internal walls are mostly abhorred here and employess are respected as the most valuable company asset. All but not limited to this greatly unleash your potential to think big, continuously grow yourself big and finally win big.
cons: Recent M&A activities has posed bit challenge to integrate this culture into new comers.

pros: opportunity to take international postings
cons:
More than I can list:
No excitement- OK but low morale and folks just going through the motions. No real sense if inclusive culture.  lots of layoffs and takes a long time to get anything done

pros: Good people to work with - highly motivated, and from a very diverse background especially in Bell Labs. Physical working environment is pleasant. Work/life balance is excellent.
cons: Salaries could be better - many are below market rate for the job, and review budgets are tiny. Business decisions get made by planners outside of Ireland, who don't necessarily have the best interests of the Irish operation at heart

review_title: Nokia seems to be a big name but not a branded
pros:
It is good comapany for manager posotion.
It is good for HR and process Team.
cons: When i joined 5yrs back i had a good image of Nokia.After joining surprised and still unable to under stand the Nokia logic. This comapny has no proper process for anything. no good tools as well. Its purely dominated by manager. Poor HR capability.Here the billable resources suffer the most.specially who joins from other company.

pros:
"Access to State of the Art technology" - a relative term
Great Work Environment
Fair treatment, without discrimination based on colour or sex
cons:
Location of work site
On site catering facilities were a pain, as the location of the facility was outside city limits it was either the messy food/ asking your wife to cook for you at 5 in the morning!

pros:
1.  Parent company Siemens and Nokia are excellent companies
2.  You can easily avoid working here, if you like that.  
3. As it is in a cost cutting mode, you can get exposure working on things beyond your experience.
cons:
1. Excessive cost cutting resulting in quality cutting
2. It is now common talk that that your performance rating has no connection to your appraisal.  Politics, smart managers, favoritism etc have greater impact on it. 
3. Managers with no people or management skills

review_title: From promising to dismal prospects for the company
pros: Decent work life balance. Vacation allowance is good. Working with people from other countries, truly multi-national. Good ethics, good pockets of technical expertise.
cons: Moral is very poor throughout the company at the moment, management are distant and detatched. There is also a very prevelant 'us and them' attitude from the management.

pros: The best thing was the getting to know the people. Good things were also the chance to work from home office, the flexible hours. I always thought t was an honour to work for the company (until the last few years) as there was a feeling of getting things done and achieving something together.
cons: Very little chances of career advancement due to constantly changing organization. Some team leads were not good at managing people - leading to a bad working environment and people constantly leaving. The pay was not very good.

review_title: Excellent or boring it's up to you
pros: Great work time balance, freedom to start-up and run your own projects, freedom to try out and make mistakes, freedom to test out in the market new ways of retailing, selling, marketing etc.
cons:
You can work 20 hours a day or 4 hours a day, not much recognition versus your contribution
Career and promotions are not directly correlated to your impact nor your results.

job_title: Business Development Manager in New York, NY
pros: Global, lots of projects, analytical culture
cons: Too much change, high chance of layoffs, bureaucratic, decisions by committee, moves too slowly, kills off entire teams, too many different teams doing duplicative things

review_title: One of the better companies to work for despite their current market position.
pros: Best work/life balance of any company I've worked for (or any that my friends have worked for). One of the better paying companies with good perks.
cons: My current position does not seem to support my growth or have the mentors I would like to push, inspire and guide me through my career.

review_title: Good company that seems unable to achieve its potential
pros: Open and transparent culture. Every employee has a voice. Ability to make an impact if you seize the opportunity. Good work/life balance - management truly lets you turn off work when you are on vacation.
cons: Too much organizational change. Ultimate lack of ownership of decisions and results in management. Reputation of the company is a 'has been', which is sometimes embarrassing.

review_title: Good company trying to manage a large merger
pros:
Once a decision has been made, everyone moves forward.  Errors are there to learn from
Builds on strengths, be able to measure performance
Values personnel growth
cons:
Decision making not always aligned with required project timeframes...
Rules applied non-uniformly across teams and personnel
Entrench to core strengths stabilizes business but timing was late

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Irving, TX
pros: Chance to grow professionally, make your own decisions, meet many people from all walks of life.  Challenging opportunity.
cons: Management is lost, if someone does not work out, get rid of them instead of loosing months on worthless re-organizational changes.  Cut the dead weight at the top, you have a bunch of loosers on the payroll and have cut many of the people that can make the company come back.

review_title: Great people, great benefits and great opportunities for those who land in the right group.
pros: People are open, straightforward and friendly.  There is a real sense of community when working there.  The benefits package is pretty good as far as 401K and vacations go.
cons:
No  advancement or even lateral movement unless you are working in the right group.  
Low pay when compared to the market.  
The constant fear that you will lose your job in the next lay off and unfortunately there's always a next lay off.

review_title: awesome company to work for. Recomended.
job_title: Senior Software Developer in London, England
pros:
Nice salary.
Depending the country, medium to high benefits like parking, doctor, massages in the office, food card, free snacks and drinks, work from home...
Company values are perfect. 
Work life balance is real, many companies should learn.
cons:
Difficult to move to different country. If you want to change your job to other country it´s really difficult.
Internal movements are possible but you have to know someone in other country to make it easier. 
Depending on the job position, you will be overloaded of work.

review_title: Wonderful place to work at, until MS took over
job_title: Fun to Work At in San Diego, CA
pros: Fair local management, worked with a great number of talented people. Loads of opportunity to learn concepts of mobile phone theory.  Most coworkers pleasant to work with. HR process was good at screening people who wouldn't have fit in. Some crunch time, but work life balance was fine.
cons: Upper management had little vision.   Some coworkers could get pigeon-holed.  Review process could be tedious.

review_title: Good company to work and plan retirement
pros:
Average/Ok  salary..
WFH option
Company lease car option available
Good leave plans (24 PL, 10 sick)
cons:
Not much option to save tax.. like no food-coupon, no broadband bill claim, lower cap on fule/maintainace bills also
Work-Life balance depends on project/account else you will screwed like worst than service company

pros:
Flexible timing
On time salary
You can be busy all the time doing the junk work which is assigned to you
cons:
1. The work promised during interview has no relation with what is assigned
2. Assures development work but gives testing
3. They search for cheap labour. Salary not competent
4. No place to sit in office as its over crowded. And no body cares about it
5. Worst cafeteria you need to stand and wait untill others finish eating
6. Calls for weekend work by jus providing lunch for the day and you get nothing else for working whole day
7. One guy doing 3 people work here.

review_title: A good company going through tough times, only to become great some day
job_title: Head of Customer Engagement, Chief Technology Officer in Sunnyvale, CA
pros:
"Respect"  is one the Nokia values and this is truly something every employee lives by. Good work life balance. Many internal opportunities to grow.
Nokia has reinvented itself many times and hopefully the future will be no different. However the industry outlook is weak and not being in a growth market means constantly making tough decisions.
cons: Continuous transformation and restructuring happens in Nokia, which can be rather demotivating for high performance teams.

pros:
Work-life balance - work pressure doesn't eat into your family time. 
Vacation - Never had a case was it was rejected - Of course you should do due diligence and apply responsibly
cons: Many take undue advantage of flexibility. In turn, it impacts company performance and time-to-market for most of the products are very high.

job_title: Human Resources Operations Specialist in Budapest
pros: Competitive benefits and salary. Good location.
cons:
Organizational culture can vary on departments, but it is shameful at HR. Thankfully has not been a victim of such, but I got the impression of them not really knowing what “diversity” means and how to properly make them feel equal. 
Colleagues are rather competitive than helpful, complete opposite of team players, really uncommunicative. 
Buddyprogam is not functioning properly. 
People dont really stay for long, since nearly everyone has the same position and stays in it, due there is no room for improvement.

review_title: It's exciting working for the world-wide devices leader, Connecting people
job_title: Network Architect in Mountain View, CA
pros: With half a billion devices sold per year, there is no other job where you have more of a chance to change humanity. That's exciting! The benefits and company values are very good, and compensation seems quite competitive compared to the rest of the industry.
cons: Large, European company is sometimes frustratingly slow to change. This is not a start-up, and there is some bureaucracy to navigate in order to be a successful player.

review_title: Make some tough decisions about legacy software and products
pros: Fair honest good engineers massive potential to leverage existing market share and billions of users
cons:
Too many re-orgs putting the same senior management team in different jobs.
re-orgs destroy the social fabric that leads to community innovation building.
Too much self preservation currently after head count reductions.

review_title: Good people, some good ideas, very slow to recognize obvious
pros: Nokia has a great work/life balance. Also, they are open to hear from people regardless of position.
cons: Senior management was very slow to act on the iPhone challenge. Also, working in satellite office meant that we had little input to our direction, at least in the case of my project.

review_title: Good for a stable job, but wihout prospects for interesting software development projects.
pros: Stable and nice working environment, a bit of financial support when on maternity leave, good medical package and flexible time window during which  one can come to work.
cons: No budget for trainings and certifications ("budget" is "frozen"), low salary compared with other, smaller companies, software development is mostly maintainence of old software from Germany. Low salary is main cause for huge workforce rotation (and both  lowering software quality and  knowledge about systems we work with)

review_title: Great company with a long road ahead
job_title: Senior Manager (Non-technical) in San Diego, CA
pros:
Good people
Lots of talent
Not a backstabbing environment
cons:
- Too many reorgs
- Sometimes have folks of questionable talent or who lack motivation and work ethic in Sr. roles
Waste an awful lot of money on European managers brought stateside -- the comp and benefits are ridiculous for some of these people...and the company is not one with a lot of extra cash right now
- Too slow in execution
- Opportunities for advancement are limited right now 
- Lots of layoffs due to market position

pros:
At Nokia the biggest advantage you have is freedom of expression - share ideas, contribute, innovate
The core culture of the company is very positive, open and flexible
The company also takes good care of its employees even in difficult times by providing bridges, good severance packages and other opportunities internally
cons: Lacked vision and failed to take into account the dynamically ever changing market of mobile phones - especially with advent of smart phones

review_title: Great company to work for.  They treat you well with good benefits, fair pay and company culture.
job_title: Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Titles don't mean a thing.  You are free to challenge management.  Very little company politics, at least from middle management on down.  Excellent work/life balance and company values.
cons: Difficult to move up the ladder unless you are willing to move to Finland.  Many midnight phone calls.

review_title: Disorganised, Chaotic, strong engineering, dire project management in R&D
pros: Some good talented people at engineer level willing to share their knowledge and help colleagues to blossom. Occasional able to work on new technologies.
cons: At the best middle and senior management is inept and incompetent at worst spiteful and malignant. Despite assertions there is no proper budget for training or development. salaries have remained static for years, pensions and healthcare badly reduced.

review_title: Best environment, work-life balance and benefits
pros: Amazing and talented colleagues, great work environment, very good perks and flexibility to take PTO when needed.
cons: Senior management totally lost. Lots of bureaucracy and heavy processes even for simple tasks. It's frustrating to see so many good and innovative engineering projects being killed because so many wrong decisions from upper management.

review_title: Nokia was a good company to work for.  For a large company, they provided a great day-to-day working environment.
pros: They attracted very capable and creative people.
cons: There was a large divide between the customer facing work force and upper management.  This made the company direction disconnected from the market place which caused their demise.

review_title: Nokia is a good place to start your carrer
pros: I think Nokia is one of the best choice for fresh graduates. Flexible working hours, good payment, secure job. You can learn a lot about telecommunications here.
cons: Long learning procces, you have to wait long to effectly contribute to the team's work.  Sometimes the morale is low and the go for an extra mile attitude is missing.

review_title: Nice colleagues, very good boss, fantastic job. We work hard but it's worth it.
pros: Lot of freedom and flexibility, very interesting job, challenging, extremely good work environment, good salary, possibility to work from home from time to time
cons: Not easy to reach Antwerp in the morning, sometimes the "administrative" tasks are overwhelming (code requests, documentation, etc...),  very tight planning forces to work extra hours sometimes, the cafeteria can be better

review_title: It was a great place to work
pros: Great company to work for. Twice yearly performance reviews, bonuses, Live Life programs, great workmates. Great technology, and lot and lots of devices to play with.
cons: They shut down after the Microsoft takeover so that was sad. Once Nokia decided to go with Windows Mobile, it was the end for the Brisbane office.

review_title: Nokia is an open company and focus on quality .
job_title: Software Test Engineer in Hangzhou, Zhejiang
pros: the communication is good,  and the work envrionment is good.  quality is important in Nokia. Nokia have more and more empolyees .and all over the world. China is an import  reasearch and development center.
cons: the promotion is narrow. and the senior employee are not more. in Nokia we have more and more develop tools. so we need more time to learn it. it will cost too many time. and some are not good.

pros:
Great work-life balance, great benefits.
Opportunity to make great positive impact on customers worldwide.
cons: Specifically for the Austin, TX office, there is in my opinion a great deal of favoritism to hire and promote close friends and family members of predominant employee group. I've witnessed comments that interview questions were provided in advance to hire family members.

job_title: Software Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
- Open door policy
- Good managers
- Friendly teammates
- Company pushes you to learn
- Good medical benefits
- Open to new technologies
cons:
- Engineers are required to do everything at once almost covering every role from scrum master, to PO, to software design and architecture
- If the company is in trouble, it won't hesitate to lessen its manpower and sacrifice a good workplace to reduce budget at the expense of its employee's welfare
- With declining manpower and poor office facilities, those who are left are still expected to deliver fast

review_title: Excellent Product, Marketing and Selling ... but everything is isolated
pros: Good Laboral Environment, Flexible Working Hours, Good Benefits, Opportunity yo Keep Learning
cons: Directive Teams and Isolated between business units, multiple overlapping functions and jobs roles between organization .. no real End to End for Solution Selling and neither Delivery.

pros:
Work:
Great importance on employee welfare. Personalized development plan every year. Many competence development programs and training. Mature Agile environment. Transparent on all employees. Flexible working time periods.

Growth:
Slow salary growth. Moderate speed on Career growth.

Benefits:
All dependents covered.  Dental, Vision, OTC, Prescribed medicine reimbursement. Meal allowance. Clothing allowance.
cons: Many top level restructuring affecting employees on the lower level (developers, PO, Managers, etc...). Slow Salary growth causes high attrition rate.

review_title: Reasonable package, but easy to hide & innovation stiffled
pros:
Hugely powerful brand
Hands on with leading / up & coming technologies
Significant opportunites to move within the company, e.g overseas etc
cons:
Stiffling bureaucracy
Acitivity often dictated by policy
Innovation has died to make way for catching up with competitiors
Silo mentality in parts

pros: Good benefits, phones and opportunity to work on new stuff. As a big size company, you can expect all the advantages of it.
cons: Too frequent changes most of which are confusing and unnecessary. Dead wood at management. Many departments function as silos. Everyone wants to protect their back during changes by politics. Very bad at integrating acquisitions.

review_title: Excellent opportunity for fresh engineers to know the telecom field.
pros:
1. one of the best trainings in the industry.
2.good starting salaries.
3.supportive work environment.
4.u always have some one to look upto.
cons:
1.If u are in the MS ,a lot depends on your Customer.NSN are very caring of their customers,so u can be required to push the limits.

2.less growth opportunities within the organization for people having not long enough association with the company.

pros: Global presence. Good product Portfolio
cons: Supply chain getting too complex. Constant re-structuring.

pros: Great for kids with limited experience
cons:
Too much micro management by people who are 'yes-men' 
It's who you know, not what you know that will get you promoted

review_title: Constant supply of interesting and challenging tasks
pros:
Good interaction between employees and management. Open and relaxed atmosphere, anyones ideas counts, you can grab opportunities and build your own success.
I saw surprisingly little office politics for a company of it's size.
Good compensation and benefits, good personal growth opportunities. Initiative is rewarded.
cons: I was there when the business collapsed. One drawback of a large company is the inertia, but with a renewed focus and much smaller scale, especially when Mobile Device business is transferred to Microsoft, innovation can hopefully happen again.

job_title: Principal Engineer in San Diego, CA
pros:
I got good resignation package!  Also I enjoyed 6 month grace period when I was laid off.
Work style was excellent.  After 5pm, office was almost empty.  Long summer holiday, longer than 2 wk is possible.  I love company culture.  Salary was relatively low.
cons: Many silos in department and even individual level!  Typical European company.  Company-level strategy changed frequently, and it led many lay-offs.  People looked lazy relatively to me :-)

review_title: Challenging work with excellent engineers but in a constantly declining US workforce.
job_title: Software Engineer in Arlington Heights, IL
pros:
The work is challenging with fairly up to date technology
The engineers are excellent and very experienced
The compensation and benefits are very competitive
cons:
There is very little US based executive management.
There have been constant layoffs both under Motorola and Nokia mostly due to off-shoring.
Decision making at the executive level seems to be slow.

pros: One of the leading Telecom vendors. Strong market position, lots of interesting projects. A lot of talented people. Work-life balance is manageable.
cons: Bonus policy is based on the global financial achievements and top management decision, rather than on personal achievements. Carrier development opportunities are not straight forward, although HR tries to change it.

job_title: Core Network Engineer in New Delhi
pros: The company provides a nice platform to learn at early stages. Nokia has a stronger presence in Managed Services division. It has a fair company policy.
cons: It could be difficult to get promotion after initial years. A lot of hierarchy is maintained sometimes. The company has a fair policy but sometimes it is entirely up to the manager to provide you with the opportunities. The line managers hold a lot of power.

pros: Work/life balance definitely supported.  Many educational opportunities and good benefits.  International environment, great at promoting diversity and flat organizational structure
cons: Salary increases were not nearly on par with competing companies mostly because of the struggling state of the phone business at the time.

review_title: A lot of bells and whistles
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Quezon City, National Capital Region
pros:
Employee benefits are top notch.
Has their own lunch catering service, gym, recreational places, room for technology dabbling, and sports activities.
A lot of fun out-of-work activities for work-life balance.
Venue for innovation, growing startups
Stock options.
Semi-flexible work hours.
cons:
A little heavy on processes
Unsatisfied employees
Micro-management
Promotes Agile, DevOps, but doesn't really practice it.
A lot of overtime work and weekend work.

review_title: Excellent place to work poor compensation and ability to grow
job_title: Software Tester in Athens, Athens, Attica
pros: Excellent and safe work place, with interesting subject and ability to move inside company . Multi different teams and products at one place  . Multinational companie with big customers.
cons: Poor compensation and ability to grow  . Good performers are not rewarded. Line / project managers     are often tottaly techical agnostic causing troubles with communication .

job_title: NTAS R&D Engineer in Athens, Athens, Attica
pros:
- Good work-life balance
- Ticket restaurant coupons
cons:
- Salaries are way below average for Greek standards
- Really hard to get a raise
- Zero incentives
- Managers are either indifferent or really pushy
- No recognition
- No career evolvement
- Climate is going from bad to worse
- Key engineers are leaving and nothing is done to keep them
- Mode of operation is really lacking and employee feedback is ignored

pros:
Staff benefits package.
Some talented individuals.
cons:
Massive internal business unit politics.
Integration of ALU not well advanced and leads to massive process overhead and lack of agility in any complex scenarios.
Inept HR, payroll, pension and benefits team.
Savage headcount reductions in key areas like pre-sales and architecture counter productive given increased targets.
Quarter by quarter short term focus.
Nokia brand

review_title: A good place to work if you are in a good team otherwise it can be hell
job_title: Graduate Engineering Trainee GET in Gurgaon, Haryana
pros:
1. Working hours arent very long
2.  Even freshers get to work on challenging projects . But it all depends on the team
cons:
1. Sometimes managers can be really rude
2.  There is not much scope for software development in Nokia.
3. Project management is not good. Many projects have been dumped after spending a lot of time and effort.

pros: I've been with Nokia since last 12 years and the journey has been more than fantastic. It is a open culture and suggestions are welcomed from all quarters. The Nokia values strings all the employees in one string and a sense of harmony prevails among all.
cons: Depending upon the vertical of work, the job profile may be easy to tiring. Not a cons though, there should be compulsory job rotation ( at least till a certain level) to understand different aspects of the organization

review_title: Nokia is good, but should be better
pros: Good team work. Very hard working and dedicated people.  Good company culture to respect people, to provide relatively loose and free discussion and speech work environment.
cons: Senior managers are slow to sense the trend of industry within these 2--3 years. Make less innovations than competitors. Kind of loose the major direction of how company should be in future.

review_title: Consensus driven to point of paralysis.
pros:
Nokia supports a great work life balance.
Respectful of personal time.
I've heard stories of Nokia being an awesome place to work in the past. I only worked there for 5 years of declining market share. It was not a great place due to the business problems - therefore salary increases were minimal.
cons:
Waste money.
Ineffective  organizational structure.
Does not empower divisions to take advantage of opportunities.
Does not understand the US market.

review_title: It is a extremely satisfying experience working here everyday 'Connecting People'.
pros: Nokia is one of the great companies to work for globally. Lots to learn, freedom to act, a truly global atmosphere to work in.
cons: The present uncertainty about the path where Nokia is treading towards. And during this time, it is difficult to look for job opportunities within the organization.

review_title: very good as an entry point in networking career
pros:
- many opportunities to develop technical skills
- very good workplace atmosphere
- no problems with working from home (on occasions)
cons:
- very low salary
- very small bonuses
- increasing workload/responsibilities without changing salary (or without additional benefits/bonuses)
- on overall compensation plan is very poor for engineers

pros: Working as a Product Specialist for Nokia in Chicago was a good experience overall. The company provided detailed training and good benefits including health, dental and vision. Company culture and values were excellent.
cons: Career advancement for anyone in the retail store was limited so growth opportunities were quite limited. In general, the company was not too up on the American market. The company was slow to keep up with smartphones and has lost marketshare. Perhaps the Windows phone operating system will be good for their future.

review_title: Too slow to change and losing talent fast
pros: Focus on work/life balance, telecommuting, 401k plan, positive work culture up until summer 2012 lay-offs
cons: Even new hires can get laid off, which makes the environment really stressful. Constant reorganizations and not enough people to do the work. Also a lot of planinng and talking vs. execution....too slow. People do not come to the office a lot, so the buzz is not there.

pros: The Telecoms industry - although it is in an identity crisis, it is at the core of, and contributes an essential part to, everyone's world today and in the future: the means to communicate.  Opportunities should be abounding.
cons: Fear: of financial contraints; of competitive moves; of restructuring activities and the impact; if able to pull off the chosen strategy.

review_title: I could not see a  productive and long term career in Nokia Siemens due to their current business performance
pros:
It ranks among the large telecom companies supplying 3G and LTE infrastructure to leading operators in the world
Global company with operations in several countries
cons: Poor business performance and uncertain future of the company. The weak management is unlikely  to be able to recover.

pros:
This company is one of the best that I have every worked for, I have an experience of over 10 years working for many companies and sectors but honestly NSN is the best.
Flexible working environment, access to a great deal of information and training, very good working relationships, unlimited opportunities for growth.
cons: The compensation and benefits are not very competitive, bot bad though. the reason might be the financial struggles that the company has been going through  in the last 3 years with serious issues in terms of affordability.

review_title: Good place for managers, but not for specialists.
pros: Workload is usually not high, so work-life balance is good. Office location is good, with good parking space.
cons: General employees of any kind are at no value at this company. You will never be promoted neither you ever get salary increase, especially if you're job grade 9 or below (in Finland). Company usually do nothing if good specialist is leaving and manager accept your resignation with the poker face.

review_title: six years ago it was nice to work there
pros: Travelled a lot and worked with a lot of different people around the world. Enjoyed the work and the money was good.
cons: Relentless cost cutting, relentless re-organization. Did not know what to do with some products (continually shifted them around from department to department). Desks got smaller (still getting smaller), even minor benefits like free tea and coffee removed.  Fired good people from the team and kept bad ones (company was afraid of lawsuits if they choose people based on performance).

pros: Nokia in Berlin has a very international culture although. It also has some interesting projects to offer.
cons:
There are so many re-orgs, basically one every 3 or 4 months. No clear direction on anything, neither from top management, nor from managers or within the teams.
No clear responsibilities. No clear career paths. Often there's simply no way to grow.
Stepping up and trying to change things for the better is usually punished, so that people simply give up after some time. Lots of lazy people, who already gave up trying to change things. Only the people remain, who enjoy a good 'work life balance' environment - everybody else is leaving.

review_title: The company has seen better times but still has potential
